'''Crasher''' is the name of several [[fictional characters]] in the [[Gobots]] toyline, and the subsequent [[Challenge of the GoBots]] cartoon and the ''[[Transformers]]'' series. She was a regular character in the Gobots cartoon and star of the film ''Gobots: Battle of the Rock Lords'' voiced by [[Marilyn Lightstone]]. She is sometimes called "'''Fracture'''" for trademark purposes. ==Gobots== {{Infobox character | name = Crasher | series = [[Challenge of the Gobots]]'', ''[[Machine Robo]] and ''[[Robo Machine]]s | image = [[File:GobotsCrasherTV.jpg|240px]] | caption = Crasher in ''Challenge of the Gobots'' | first = "The Battle for Gobotron" | last = ''[[Gobots: Battle of the Rock Lords]]'' | creator = | portrayer = | voice = [[Marilyn Lightstone]] | nickname = | alias = | species = Gobot | gender = Female | occupation = | title = | family = | spouse = | significantother = | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = | lbl1 = Japanese name |data1 = Porsche Robo | lbl2 = Release number |data2 = MR-20 | lbl21 = Abilities |data21 = Energy blasts, [[flight]], [[shapeshifting]], superhuman durability, [[superhuman strength]] | lbl22 = Affiliation |data22 = Renegade Gobot | lbl23 = Alternate mode |data23 = [[Porsche 956]] }} The female Crasher was one of [[Cy-Kill]]'s most loyal Renegades, despite having a somewhat manic personality. One of her favoured pastimes is participating in demolition derbies.{{Cite book | title=Totally Tubular '80s | last=Bellomo | first=Mark | year=2010 | publisher=Krause Publications| ISBN=1-4402-1282-1 | page= 90=93}} She is considered reckless.{{Cite journal | author = | title = News | journal = Computer & Video Games| volume = 1 | issue = 61 | page = 8 | date = |url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=C+VG/Issue061/Pages/CVG06100008.jpg}} Under interrogation, she admitted to having a crush on [[Leader-1]] before the Guardians and Renegades began their struggle. Unlike most Gobots, she rarely seems to use her hand-mounted blasters, instead using a trademark attack wherein she stamps her foot on the ground to create a powerful earthquake-style energy discharge that could track its victim in much the same manner as a heat-seeking missile. Crasher's seeming state of near-madness effectively renders her fearless, and she has an ongoing grudge with the Guardian [[Turbo (Gobots)|Turbo]], rarely avoiding a chance to battle him. However, she tends to take any defeat or challenge very personally.http://www.oafe.net/yo/tfm_frac.php Despite her gender, unlike many 1980s female cartoon characters, Crasher is shown to be treated equally compared to her male counterparts, and is feared by most Guardians.Going, Going, Gobots by Matt Carara, Toyfare Magazine #123, November 2007, page 80-82 Crasher enjoyed Gobot demolition derbies and at one time had a crush on [[Leader-1]]. According to Hasbro employees Crasher was the inspiration for the Decepticon [[Fracture (Transformers)|Fracture]].http://www.toplessrobot.com/2011/04/8_things_you_didnt_know_about_gobots_and_probably.php ===Animated series=== Crasher appears in almost every episode, usually as a featured character. In the pilot Crasher and Cop-Tur aid Cy-Kill when he steals the astrobeam and escapes Gobotron to Earth.{{Cite episode |title= The Battle for Gobotron|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Alan Burnett, Jeff Segal and Tom Ruegger |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= September 8, 1984 |season= 1|number= 1}} Cy-Kill, [[Cop-Tur]], Crasher, [[Geeper-Creeper]], [[Pincher (Gobots)|Pincher]], and [[Snoop (Gobots)|Snoop]] attack a lab, but it is defended by Leader-1, Baron Von Joy, Blaster, Dozer, [[Dumper (Gobots)|Dumper]], [[Road Ranger (Gobots)|Road Ranger]], Scooter, [[Scratch (Gobots)|Scratch]] and [[Turbo (Gobots)|Turbo]]. Although the Guardians were winning the battle, an accidental backfire from Baron Von Joy's weapon allows the Renegades to escape.{{Cite episode |title= It's The Thought That Counts|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= |season= 1|number= 6}} [[Cy-Kill]], Cop-Tur, Crasher and [[Snoop (Gobots)|Snoop]] attack [[Leader-1]], Turbo, [[Scooter (Gobots)|Scooter]] and [[Small Foot (Gobots)|Small Foot]]. Crasher wounds Small Foot. After attaining recordings of the Guardians the Renegades retreat. Using the recordings Cy-Kill has [[Herr Fiend]] program robot duplicates of the Guardians. When demonstrating [[Space Bender]] weapon to Unicom, Leader-1 learns that the Renegades ware attacking Washington. The Renegades ambush Leader-1 and replaced him with his duplicate. Leading the [[Command Center (Gobots)|Command Center]] back to Gobotron and getting rid of Scooter and Small Foot the Renegades then release duplicates of [[Path Finder (Gobots)|Path Finder]], [[Rest-Q]], [[Van Guard]] and Turbo. Small Foot and Scooter are able to capture the Turbo duplicate and learn where their friends are being held. Cy-Kill then replaces [[Good Night (Gobots)|Good Night]]. Using the duplicate Turbo the Guardians infiltrate the Renegade base, free the captured Guardians and escape from [[Spoons (Gobots)|Spoons]] and [[Fitor]]. Although blocked by the Renegades, Scooter uses a hologram of [[Zod (Gobots)|Zod]] to make the Renegades flee. Making it back to Gobotron the Guardians are attacked by the Guardian duplicates. The real Guardians are able to defeat their duplicates with the aid of the real [[Zeemon]], [[Hans-Cuff]] and Rest-Q. Cy-Kill then arrives in [[Thrustor]] with more duplicates, but Small Foot is able to stop with robots using the Space Bender, which fuses their robot brains.{{Cite episode |title= Doppleganger|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= |season= 1|number= 23}} Scooter and [[Small Foot (Gobots)|Small Foot]] join Nick and A.J. to watch a car stunt show which is attacked by Crasher, [[BuggyMan]] and [[Fly Trap]]. Small Foot fights Buggyman and defeats him, but the Renegades regain the upper hand until the Guardians are rescued by Leader-1 and Turbo who arrived in [[Power Suit (Gobots)|Power Suit]]s. Cy-Kill vows to gain Power Suits for the Renegades. Scooter decides he needed more firepower, so he has [[Baron Von Joy]] remove his damaged holo projector in favor of a blaster unit. [[Screw Head]], [[Bad Boy (Gobots)|Bad Boy]] and Cop-Tur are sent to attack Unicom bases and distract the Guardians while Cy-Kill, Crasher and Scorp attempt to take the suits from the Guardian Command Center. Small Foot and Scooter are able to delay the Renegades until Leader-1 and Turbo return to chase away the Renegades. Realizing he is a better Guardian with his holo projector, Scooter has it reinstalled. {{Cite episode |title= Scooter Enhanced|episodelink= |series= Challenge of the GoBots|serieslink= Challenge of the GoBots|credits= Written by Jeff Segal, Kelly Ward and Mark Young |network= First-run syndication|station= |airdate= November 24, 1985|season= 1|number= 55}} Crasher was among the Renegade Gobot forces who aided the [[Rock Lord]] Magmar on the planet Cordax.{{cite video |people=[[Ray Patterson (animator)|Ray Patterson]] (Director), Kay Wright (Producer), Jeff Segal (Writer) |date=1986-03-21 |title=GoBots: Battle of the Rock Lords |format= |medium=Motion picture |publisher=[[Clubhouse Pictures]]}} {{cite book|title=The Great Robot Book |author=Texe W. Earth Chopper-style Motorcycle |series =''[[Transformers: Robots in Disguise (2015 TV series)|Transformers: Robots in Disguise (2015)]]'' |engvoice =[[Kevin Pollak]] |japanvoice =[[Anri Katsu]] }} The '''Fracture''' name is used once again, this time for a male character from ''[[Transformers: Robots in Disguise (2015 TV series)|Transformers: Robots in Disguise]]'' (the 2015 animated follow-up to the previous series ''[[Transformers: Prime]]''). This version of Fracture is a [[bounty hunter]] who has a rivalry with the Autobot bounty hunter, [[Drift (Transformers)|Drift]]. He transforms into a purple motorcycle and is the only one that doesn't have an animal motif for his robot mode in the first season. He has two [[Mini-Con]] partners, [[Airazor]] and Divebomb, voiced by [[Roger Craig Smith]] and [[Khary Payton]], respectively, who transform into missiles which launch from Fracture's shoulders. Like Drift, Fracture's Mini-Cons seemingly form part of his alternate mode as they are seen transforming with him. ===Animated series=== Fracture debuted in the episode 12, entitled "Hunting Season". He traveled to Earth to collect the bounty the Cybertron High Council put on Bumblebee, but when Drift steps in to defend Bumblebee and his ship is hijacked by the Autobots, Fracture stayed on Earth and joined [[Steeljaw]]'s gang. In his following appearances, he would join Steeljaw's pack in attempting to break out the Decepticons that the Autobots had already captured, only to fail repeatedly. In the first-season finale, Fracture attacks the Autobot base when only Fixit, Denny and Russel are there. The three prepare to fight Fracture and his Mini-Cons, only to find that a newly resurrected [[Optimus Prime]] has already defeated them. Despite not being an ''Alchemor'' prisoner, the defeated Fracture (and his Mini-Cons) was presumably placed in a stasis cell before Optimus when off to fight [[Fallen (Transformers)|Megatronus]]. ===Video games=== Fracture appears as an unlockable character in the mobile game for ''[[Transformers: Robots in Disguise (2015 TV series)|Transformers: Robots in Disguise]]''. ===Toys=== *'''''Robots in Disguise'' One-Step Changer Decepticon Fracture''' (2015) :Part of the third wave of ''Robots in Disguise'' One-Step Changers, Fracture transforms from robot to chopper in one step. For some reason, his optics were painted blue instead of red. *'''''Robots in Disguise'' Deployer Decepticon Fracture''' (2015) :This Warrior-sized mold of Fracture transforms from a Cybertronian Chopper Bike to a robot. In robot mode, pulling down on a lever on Fracture's back swings the launcher downward to fire the loaded Mini-Con; in vehicle mode, it becomes his bike's sidecar, and the Mini-Con is launched by pressing a button on top of it. The launcher is designed with a "safety" switch on its underside that prevents the button from being pressed unless the bike is placed on a surface. The included Airazor transforms into a torpedo, and comes with a sprue of extra weapons and armor. Most of these extra pieces attach to Airazor to make his alternate mode resemble a tiny spacecraft; he also comes with an teeny-weeny little pair of energy swords, which he can hold in his hands or store on his legs, and which can also mount on Fracture's forearms. Fracture features a Mini-Con mounting port on his left elbow, where Airazor or any other Mini-Con can attach. As with all ''Robots in Disguise'' figures, all Fracture toys have a scannable insignia on the right side of his front wheel. {{short description| Autonomous underwater vehicle for exploring sinkholes in Mexico }} [[File:Depthx commons détouré.jpg|thumb|Deep Phreatic Thermal Explorer]] The '''Deep Phreatic Thermal Explorer''' ('''DEPTHX''') is an [[autonomous underwater vehicle]] designed and built by [[Stone Aerospace]], an [[aerospace engineering]] firm based in [[Austin]], [[Texas]]. It was designed to [[Autonomous robot|autonomously]] explore and map underwater [[sinkholes]] in northern Mexico, as well as collect water and wall core samples. The DEPTHX vehicle was the first of three vehicles to be built by Stone Aerospace which were funded by [[NASA]] with the goal of developing technology that can explore the oceans of [[Jupiter]]'s moon [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] to look for [[extraterrestrial life]].<ref name="popsci">[http://www.popsci.com/military-aviation-space/article/2007-02/robot-subs-space "Robot Subs in Space"]. ''[[Popular Science]]''. 1 Feb 2007.</ref><ref name=ieee>[http://spectrum.ieee.org/computing/hardware/swimming-to-europa "Swimming to Europa"]. ''[[IEEE Spectrum]]''. Sept 2007.</ref><ref>[https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2012/04/bill-stone-laser-powered-europa-rover/ "Cryobots Could Drill Into Icy Moons With Remote Fiber-Optic Laser Power"]. ''[[Wired magazine]]''. 19 April 2012.</ref>
DEPTHX was a collaborative project for which Stone Aerospace was the [[principal investigator]]. Co-investigators included [[Carnegie Mellon University]], which was responsible for the navigation and guidance software, the [[Southwest Research Institute]], which built the vehicle's science [[Payload (air and space craft)|payload]], and research scientists from the [[University of Texas at Austin]], the [[Colorado School of Mines]], and [[NASA]] [[Ames Research Center]].<ref>[http://www.frc.ri.cmu.edu/depthx/about.html About the DEPTHX Project]. [[Carnegie Mellon Field Robotics Center]]. Retrieved 26 April 2012.</ref>
== History == [[File:depthx.jpg|thumb|right|DEPTHX robot being lowered into La Pilita, one of several water-filled sinkholes in [[Sistema Zacaton]] (in northeastern Mexico). Photo by Marc Airhart, [[Jackson School of Geosciences]], March 2007.]]
In 1999, [[William Stone (caver)|Bill Stone]] had been involved in an underwater [[surveying]] project in [[Wakulla Springs]], [[Florida]]. For that project, Stone had devised a digital wall mapper that was propelled by a [[diver propulsion vehicle]] and steered by divers which was designed to create a 3-D map of Wakulla Springs using an array of sonars, as well as a suite of other sophisticated sensors.<ref name=ieee /><ref>[http://usdct.org/wakulla2-technology.php Wakulla 2 Technology]. U.S. Deep Caving Team. Retrieved 27 April 2012.</ref> The success of this project, the Wakulla Springs 2 Project, attracted the interest of [[Planetary science|planetary scientist]] [[Dan Durda]] from the Southwest Research Institute, who wished to create a similar piece of technology to explore the oceans of Europa, but one that could drive itself autonomously. Stone accepted the challenge, and several collaborative proposals were submitted to NASA. It wasn't until 2003 that NASA would finally fund DEPTHX as a three-year, $5 million project.<ref name=ieee />
The vehicle underwent several different design concepts over the next couple of years as engineers at Stone Aerospace explored various options. Initial designs focused on a less [[ellipsoidal]] design, however these designs were abandoned due to concerns that such a shape would be difficult to maneuver out of the potentially tight spots it might encounter during the exploration of unknown territory. It was also during this time that the DEPTHX team did a field campaign at [[Cenote]] [[Zacatón]] using a drop [[CTD (instrument)|sonde]] to acquire some initial data for the software team, which itself contributed to the overall design changes. The final design was decided upon in 2006, at which point construction of the vehicle began.<ref name=history>[https://archive.is/20130105124702/http://www.stoneaerospace.com/about-us/about-us-history.php Stone Aerospace History]. Stone Aerospace. Retrieved: 28 April 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.stoneaerospace.com/news-/news-zacaton.php News: Zacaton 1 Field Campaign] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120912182200/http://www.stoneaerospace.com/news-/news-zacaton.php |date=2012-09-12 }}. Stone Aerospace. Retrieved 28 April 2012.</ref>
The completed vehicle was about {{convert|7|ft|m}} in diameter and weighed about {{convert|3300|lb|kg}}. It had redundant navigation systems including 54 sonars, an [[inertial measurement unit]], [[Doppler Velocity Log|doppler velocity logger]], as well as depth gauges and [[accelerometers]]. Propulsion systems were also redundant, having six thrusters and two equivalent battery stacks. It was outfitted with a variable [[buoyancy]] system, and finally with the science payload that included the ability to take in water and solid core samples for later analysis, as well as an onboard microscope to analyze water samples in real time.<ref name="popsci" /><ref name="depthx">[http://www.stoneaerospace.com/products-pages/products-DEPTHX.php DEPTHX (DEep Phreatic THermal eXplorer)] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20151122212722/http://www.stoneaerospace.com/products-pages/products-DEPTHX.php |date=2015-11-22 }}. Stone Aerospace. Retrieved 26 April 2012.</ref>
==Accomplishments==
During the DEPTHX 2007 deployment, the vehicle was able to create 3-D maps of four cenotes in Sistema Zacatón in [[Tamaulipas]], [[Mexico]]. This was the first autonomous system to explore and map a [[Subterranea (geography)|subterranean]] cavern. The mapping of Cenote Zacatón was particularly notable because its depth was previously unknown, as human divers had not been successful in attempts to reach the bottom. DEPTHX created the first map of the bottom of Zacatón, which has a depth of over {{convert|1000|ft|m|disp=sqbr}}.<ref>[http://www.wondermondo.com/Countries/NA/Mexico/Tamaulipas/SistemaZacaton.htm Sistema Zacatón]. Wondermondo. Retrieved 26 April 2012.</ref> DEPTHX was the first robotic system of any kind to implement [[three-dimensional]] [[simultaneous localization and mapping]] (SLAM). It was also the first such system to make its own decisions on where and how to collect samples.<ref>[http://www.stoneaerospace.com/products-pages/products-DEPTHX.php DEPTHX (DEep Phreatic THermal eXplorer)] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20151122212722/http://www.stoneaerospace.com/products-pages/products-DEPTHX.php |date=2015-11-22 }}. Stone Aerospace. Retrieved 28 April 2012.</ref> From these samples, at least three new [[Phylum|divisions]] of bacteria were discovered.<ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1462-2920.2010.02324.x/abstract A comparative molecular analysis of water-filled limestone sinkholes in north-eastern Mexico]. Wiley Online Library. 25 August 2010.</ref>
The success of the DEPTHX mission led to the funding of the follow-on project, [[ENDURANCE]]. The ENDURANCE vehicle reused the frame and a number of systems from the DEPTHX vehicle, but was considerably reconfigured for the needs of the [[Antarctic]] environment.<ref name=ieee />
== Fieldwork timeline == <!--Contradictions: So when it started surveys in Zacaton? Jan. 2007 or May 2007?-->
* January 25–27, 2007 - The DEPTHX Team begins surveying the world's deepest water-filled sinkhole, Cenote Zacatón.<ref name="stoneaerospace.com">[http://www.stoneaerospace.com/news-/news-zacaton-mission1.php DEPTHX: Zacaton - Mission 1] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130105012741/http://www.stoneaerospace.com/news-/news-zacaton-mission1.php |date=2013-01-05 }}. Stone Aerospace. Jan/Feb 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.frc.ri.cmu.edu/projects/depthx/depthxWriteups/depthx_jan2007writeup.html DEPTHX Field Notes]. Carnegie Mellon University. {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} [[File:Parepa-Rosa, Euphrosyne, 1836-1874.jpg|upright|thumb|Euphrosyne Parepa-Rosa]] '''Euphrosyne Parepa-Rosa''' (7 May 1836 – 21 January 1874) was a British [[opera]]tic [[soprano]] who established the [[Carl Rosa Opera Company]] together with her husband [[Carl Rosa]]. Parepa's [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|aristocratic father]] died soon after her birth, and her mother turned to the stage to support them. Parepa made her operatic debut in 1855, at age 16, and soon earned enthusiastic reviews in the major London opera houses. In 1867, the widowed Parosa married the violinist and conductor Carl Rosa in New York and founded an opera company with Parepa as the leading lady; they toured successfully in America for several years. After their return to Britain with ambitious plans for their opera company, Parepa fell ill and died in 1874 at only 37 years of age.
==Early life and career== [[File:Parepasculpture.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Bust of Parepa-Rosa at the [[Royal Academy of Music]]]] Euphrosyne Parepa was born in [[Edinburgh]], Scotland, to the [[soprano]] Elisabeth Seguin (b. 1812, sister of [[Bass (voice type)|basso]] Arthur Edward Seguin) and the [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|Wallachian boyar]] Demetrius Parepa, Baron Georgiades de Boyescu of [[Bucharest]].<ref name=Illustrated>"Madame Parepa-Rosa", ''[[Illustrated London News]]'', 7 February 1874, p. 129</ref> Her father died when Parepa was an infant, leaving her young mother impoverished. Parepa's mother turned to the stage to support her child and herself and trained the girl in singing.<ref name=NYtimesobit>{{citation|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C07EFDB173BEF34BC4B51DFB766838F669FDE|title=Obituary: Euphrosyne Parepa-Rosa| publisher=[[The New York Times]]| date=23 January 1874|accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref>
Her operatic début was in 1855 at the age of 16 in [[Malta]] as Amina in ''[[La Sonnambula]]'', followed by engagements in Italy, Spain and Portugal. She gave her first London performance at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]], in the role of Elvira in ''[[I Puritani]]'', with the [[Royal Italian Opera]] company, with whom she spent the 1857 season.<ref name=Grove>Rosenthal, Harold and Elizabeth Forbes. [https://doi.org/10.1093/gmo/9781561592630.article.20896 "Parepa(-Rosa), Euphrosyne (De Boyescu, Parepa)"], Grove Music Online, 20 January 2001, accessed 22 May 2018</ref> The Royal Italian Opera company held their 1856–57 season at the Lyceum because the [[Royal Opera House]] was being remodeled after a fire. See Obituary: "Madame Parepa Rosa", ''[[The Times]]'', 23 January 1874, p. 10</ref> The critic of ''[[The Observer]]'' wrote of this introduction: "Parepa possesses a soprano voice of excellent quality and remarkable compass. She acts and sings well. Her version of "''Son vergine vezzosa''" elicited applause terminating in a recall, and … [after the ''finale''] she was again called for. … '''"Qui la voce"''' … was correctly and brilliantly executed; and the ''artiste'' was again summoned back to the stage to receive the homage of the audience."<ref>"Royal Italian Opera: First Appearance of Mdlle. Parepa", ''[[The Observer]]'', 25 May 1857, p. 6</ref>
From 1859 to 1865, she appeared in opera at both [[Royal Opera House]] in [[Covent Garden]] and at [[Her Majesty's Theatre]], becoming known for such roles as Leonora in ''[[Il trovatore]]'', Zerlina in ''[[Fra Diavolo]]'' and Elvira in ''[[La muette de Portici]]''.<ref name=Grove/> During this time, she participated in two operatic premieres, creating the title role in [[Alfred Mellon]]'s ''Victorine'' in 1859 and the role of Mabel in [[George Alexander Macfarren]]'s opera ''Helvellyn'' in 1864. She also was a successful [[oratorio]] and concert soloist, in constant demand in Britain and beyond.<ref name=NYtimesobit/> She sang with [[Charles Santley]] at the opening of the [[Oxford Music Hall]] in 1861, appeared before the [[Royal Philharmonic Society]] in [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]]'s ''[[Paradise and the Peri]]'' and participated in the 19th-century English revival of the music of [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]], performing at the Handel festivals of 1862 and 1865, and in Germany.<ref name=Grove/><ref>R. Elkin. ''Royal Philharmonic'', Ryder: London (1946), p. 63</ref>
==Marriages and later years== Her first husband, Army Captain H. de Wolfe Carvelle, died in Peru in 1865, sixteen months after their wedding.<ref name=NYtimesobit/> She travelled to the United States in 1865 with cornetist Levy and violinist [[Carl Rosa]], the latter of whom she married in New York City in 1867.<ref name=Grove/> Together they quickly established the Parepa-Rosa English Opera Company there, featuring her as the leading soprano, which became popular, and which introduced opera to places in America that had never staged it before. They opened at the [[Fourteenth Street Theatre|French Theatre on Fourteenth Street]], New York City, in September 1869 with a performance of [[Michael William Balfe|Balfe]]'s opera ''The Puritan's Daughter'', with Parepa singing the title role. The subsequent tour of the eastern and midwestern states included a repertoire that ranged from ''[[The Bohemian Girl]]'' and ''[[Maritana]]'' to Weber's ''[[Der Freischütz]]'' and ''Oberon''.<ref name=Carl>{{citation|url=http://www.carlrosaopera.co.uk/history/uk-ushistory.asp|title=The Carl Rosa Opera Company: American and British History|publisher=Carl Rosa Company Ltd|accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1870, the Parepa-Rosa Opera Company returned to Britain and then appeared in Italian opera at [[Cairo]], Egypt, followed by a return to America for another successful tour in 1871–72.<ref name=Carl/> In 1872, Parepa sang at the [[Lower Rhine Festival]] in [[Düsseldorf]], and they then returned to London, where she sang Donna Anna in ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' and the title role in ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]'' at the Royal Opera House.<ref name=Illustrated/><ref name=Grove/> In September 1873, the company changed its name to [[Carl Rosa Opera Company|Carl Rosa's English Opera]], since Parepa was pregnant.<ref name=Carl/>
Parepa died in London, after an illness, at the age of 37 while preparing to sing Elsa in an English version of [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s ''[[Lohengrin (opera)|Lohengrin]]'' as part of her husband's planned season a [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]]; after her death, Rosa cancelled the season.<ref name=Illustrated/><ref>Obituary: "Madame Parepa Rosa", ''The Times'', 23 January 1874, p. 10</ref> She is buried at [[Highgate cemetery]].<ref>Legge, R. H., revised by J. Gilliland. [https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/21264 "Rosa, Euphrosyne Parepa (''née'' Euphrosyne Parepa de Boyesku or Boyescu)"], ''Oxford [[Dictionary of National Biography]]'', 23 September 2004, accessed 22 May 2018</ref> After her death, Rosa endowed the Parepa-Rosa Scholarship at the [[Royal Academy of Music]] in her memory.<ref name=Grove/>
==Reputation== William Winter wrote that "Great vocal powers have seldom found such ample or such touching expression as those of Parepa-Rosa did in the first act of ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]''. … [O]ne of her best successes was made as Rosina in ''[[The Barber of Seville]]'' ... to indicate the versatility of her talents and the scope and thoroughness of her culture."<ref>Winter, William. [https://books.google.com/books?id=lJSYCwf6VaQC&pg=PA253 ''Brief Chronicles''], Ayer Publishing (1970) {{ISBN|0-8337-3826-7}}</ref> Her obituary in ''[[Illustrated London News]]'' stated: "Her voice was a genuine soprano, of extensive compass and fine quality, while her highly-cultivated execution and her general musical knowledge gave her exceptional advantages, both mechanical and intellectual".<ref name=Illustrated/>
Her achievements were recognised by the [[Royal Philharmonic Society|Philharmonic Society of London]] (now the Royal Philharmonic Society) with the rare award of their Gold Medal in 1872.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.royalphilharmonicsociety.org.uk/awards/gold_medal/goldmedalrecipients/|title=RPS Gold Medal Recipients Since 1870|publisher=Royal Philharmonic Society|accessdate=30 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509113938/http://www.royalphilharmonicsociety.org.uk/awards/gold_medal/goldmedalrecipients/|archivedate=9 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

{{Redirect|Gavage|the medical procedure in general|Feeding tube}} [[Image:Forcefeeding.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A [[suffragette]] is force-fed in [[Holloway (HM Prison)|HM Prison Holloway]] in the UK during [[hunger strike]]s for [[women's suffrage]].<ref name=Pankhurst433>{{cite book |last=Pankhurst |first=Emmeline |authorlink=Emmeline Pankhurst |title=The Suffragette |year=1911 |location=New York |publisher=Sturgis & Walton Company |page=433}}</ref>]] '''Force-feeding''' is the practice of feeding a human or other animal against their will. The term "'''gavage'''" ({{IPAc-en|pron|ɡ|ə|ˈ|v|ɑː|ʒ}}) refers to supplying a nutritional substance by means of a small plastic [[feeding tube]] passed through the nose ([[nasogastric tube|nasogastric]]) or mouth (orogastric) into the stomach. In hospitals, some psychiatric patients can be restrained so sedatives can be injected into them; this happens if patients have been non-compliant with their instructions.
== Of humans == Soviet dissident [[Vladimir Bukovsky]] described how he was force-fed: "The feeding pipe was thick, thicker than my nostril, and would not go in. Blood came gushing out of my nose and tears down my cheeks, but they kept pushing until the cartilages cracked. I guess I would have screamed if I could, but I could not with the pipe in my throat. I could breathe neither in nor out at first; I wheezed like a drowning man — my lungs felt ready to burst. The doctor also seemed ready to burst into tears, but she kept shoving the pipe farther and farther down. Only when it reached my stomach could I resume breathing, carefully. Then she poured some slop through a funnel into the pipe that would choke me if it came back up. They held me down for another half-hour so that the liquid was absorbed by my stomach and could not be vomited back, and then began to pull the pipe out bit by bit."<ref>[[Daily Kos]]: [http://fenwaysteve.dailykos.com/storyonly/2005/12/18/19365/937 "The WaPo prints a torture story."]</ref>
"The unfortunate patients had their mouth clamped shut, had a rubber tube inserted into their mouth or nostril. They keep on pressing it down until it reaches your esophagus. A china funnel is attached to the other end of the tube and a cabbage-like mixture poured down the tube and through to the stomach. This was an unhealthy practice, as the food might have gone into their lungs and caused [[pneumonia]]."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wma.net/en/30publications/10policies/c18/ |title=Guidelines for Physicians Concerning Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment in Relation to Detention and Imprisonment |website=wma.net |publisher=[[World Medical Association]] |access-date=12 December 2015|quote=}}</ref>
=== In prisons === Some countries force-feed prisoners when they go on [[hunger strike]]. It has been prohibited since 1975 by the [[Declaration of Tokyo]] of the [[World Medical Association]], provided that the prisoner is "capable of forming an unimpaired and rational judgment". The violation of this prohibition may be carried out in a manner that can be categorised as [[torture]], as it may be extremely painful and result in severe bleeding and spreading of various diseases via the exchanged blood and mucus, especially when conducted with dirty equipment on a prison population.<ref>[[BBC News]]: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4569626.stm "UN concern at Guantanamo feeding."]</ref> Large feeding pipes are traditionally used on hunger striking prisoners<ref name=BostonGlobe2005-12-30/> whereas thin pipes are preferred in hospitals.
====United Kingdom==== [[Image:Djuna Barnes Clipping.jpg|thumb|left|Clipping from ''World Magazine'', September 6, 1914]]
[[Suffragettes]] who had been imprisoned while campaigning for [[votes for women]] went on hunger strike and were force fed. (This lasted until the [[Prisoners (Temporary Discharge for Ill Health) Act 1913|Prisoners (Temporary Discharge for Ill Health) Act]] of 1913, better known as the Cat and Mouse Act, whereby debilitated prisoners would be released, allowed to recover, and then re-arrested.) Rubber tubes were inserted through the mouth (only occasionally through the nose) and into the stomach, and food poured down; the suffragettes were held down by force while the instruments were inserted into their bodies, an experience which has been likened to [[rape]].<ref>Purvis, June; ''Emmeline Pankhurst'', London: Routledge, p 134, {{ISBN|0-415-23978-8}}</ref> In a smuggled letter, [[Sylvia Pankhurst]] described how the warders held her down and forced her mouth open with a steel gag. Her gums bled, and she vomited most of the liquid up afterwards.<ref>[[Martin Pugh (author)|Pugh, Martin]]; ''The Pankhursts'', UK: Penguin Books, 2001, p 259, {{ISBN|0-14-029038-9}}</ref>
[[Emmeline Pankhurst]], founder of the [[Women's Social and Political Union]], was horrified by the screams of women being force-fed in [[Holloway (HM Prison)|HM Prison Holloway]]. She wrote: "Holloway became a place of horror and torment. Sickening scenes of violence took place almost every hour of the day, as the doctors went from cell to cell performing their hideous office. …I shall never while I live forget the suffering I experienced during the days when those cries were ringing in my ears." When prison officials tried to enter her cell, Pankhurst, in order to avoid being force-fed, raised a clay jug over her head and announced: "If any of you dares so much as to take one step inside this cell I shall defend myself."<ref name=Pankhurst252>{{cite book |last=Pankhurst |first=Emmeline |authorlink=Emmeline Pankhurst |title=My Own Story |year=1914 |location=London |publisher=Virago Limited (1979) |ISBN=0-86068-057-6 |pages=251 & 252}}</ref>
In 1914, [[Frances Parker]], another suffragette, was being force-fed by the rectum in the Perth prison: "Thursday morning, 16th July ... the three wardresses appeared again. One of them said that if I did not resist, she would send the others away and do what she had come to do as gently and as decently as possible. I consented. This was another attempt to feed me by the rectum, and was done in a cruel way, causing me great pain. She returned some time later and said she had ‘something else’ to do. I took it to be another attempt to feed me in the same way, but it proved to be a grosser and more indecent outrage, which could have been done for no other purpose than torture. It was followed by soreness, which lasted for several days."<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.johndclare.net/Women1_Forcefeeding_Purvis.htm | title = Force-feeding extracts from Purvis | website = www.johndclare.net | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
[[Djuna Barnes]], the American journalist, agreed to submit to force-feeding for a 1914 ''[[New York World]]'' magazine article. Barnes wrote, "If I, play acting, felt my being burning with revolt at this brutal usurpation of my own functions, how they who actually suffered the ordeal in its acutest horror must have flamed at the violation of the sanctuaries of their spirits." She concluded, "I had shared the greatest experience of the bravest of my sex."<ref> Mills, Eleanor; with Kira Cochrane (eds.) (2005). Journalistas: 100 Years of the Best Writing and Reporting by Women Journalists. New York: Carroll & Graf. {{ISBN|0-7867-1667-3}}. p 163–166.</ref>
The United Kingdom also used forcible feeding techniques against [[Irish Republicans]] during their struggle for independence. In 1917 Irish prisoner [[Thomas Ashe]] died as a result of complications from such a feeding while incarcerated at [[Dublin]]'s [[Mountjoy Prison|Mountjoy Jail]]. The outrage of Ashe's death from the Irish public was so great that force feeding has never been used in Ireland again since.<ref name=CcrHungerStrikes2002-2005> {{cite news |url = http://ccrjustice.org/files/Final%20Hunger%20Strike%20Report%20Sept%202005.pdf |title = The Guantánamo Prisoner Hunger Strikes & Protests: February 2002 – August 2005 |publisher = [[Center for Constitutional Rights]] |date = 2005-09-08 |author = [[Barbara Olshansky]], [[Gitanjali Gutierrez]] |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fccrjustice.org%2Ffiles%2FFinal%2520Hunger%2520Strike%2520Report%2520Sept%25202005.pdf&date=2010-01-21 |archivedate = 2010-01-21 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
====United States==== {{main|Guantanamo hunger strikes}} [[File:Restraint chair used for enteral feeding -b.jpg|thumb|[[Guantanamo Bay detention camp|Guantanamo]] captives who will not comply with force-feeding have their arms, legs and head restrained in a feeding chair. They remain strapped in the chair until the nutrient is digested, to prevent induced vomiting.]] {{Commons category|Guantanamo force-feeding}}
Under [[United States]] jurisdiction, force-feeding is frequently used in the U.S. military prison in [[Guantanamo Bay detainment camp|Guantanamo Bay]], prompting in March 2006 an open letter by 250 doctors in ''[[The Lancet]]'', warning that, in their opinion, the participation of any doctor is contrary to the rules of the [[World Medical Association]].<ref name=Bbc2006-03-10>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4790742.stm | publisher=BBC News | date=2006-03-10 | title=Doctors attack U.S. over Guantanamo | accessdate=2006-03-15 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Famericas%2F4790742.stm&date=2010-01-21 | archivedate=2010-01-21 | quote=The letter, in the medical journal The Lancet, said doctors who used restraints and force-feeding should be punished by their professional bodies. | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref><ref name=BostonGlobe2005-12-30>{{cite news | url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2005/12/30/46_guantanamo_detainees_join_hunger_strike/ | publisher=Boston Globe | date=2005-12-30 | title=46 Guantanamo detainees join hunger strike | accessdate=2007-09-17 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.boston.com%2Fnews%2Fnation%2Fwashington%2Farticles%2F2005%2F12%2F30%2F46_guantanamo_detainees_join_hunger_strike%2F&date=2010-01-21 | archivedate=2010-01-21 | first=Charlie | last=Savage | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://newstandardnews.net/content/index.cfm/items/2719 | publisher=The New Standard | date=2005-12-30 | title=Gitmo Hunger Strikers' Numbers Grow | accessdate=2007-09-17 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnewstandardnews.net%2Fcontent%2Findex.cfm%2Fitems%2F2719&date=2010-01-21 | archivedate=2010-01-21 | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref> Retired Major General [[Paul E. Vallely]] visited Guantanamo and reported on the process of force-feeding:<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.frontpagemag.com/Articles/Read.aspx?GUID={49DE2543-29F8-4F6F-8372-85DF58E38ADD} | title=A View from Inside Gitmo | date=May 5, 2006 | publisher=[[FrontPage Magazine]] | accessdate = 2007-09-16}}</ref> {{quotation|They have to restrain the prisoners when they feed them because they attack the nurses. They spit in their faces. They're simply restrained for 20 minutes so they can be fed [[Ensure]]. They get their choice of four flavors of Ensure. It's put in a very unobtrusive feeding tube smaller than a normal straw and it's put in there for 20 minutes, so they get breakfast, lunch, and dinner.}}
In the 2009 case ''[[Lantz v. Coleman]]'',<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=2119936130691213027&hl=en&as_sdt=2&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr ''Lantz v. Coleman''], 978 A. 2d 164 (Conn. Super. Ct. 2009)</ref> the Connecticut Superior Court authorized the state Department of Correction to force-feed a competent prisoner who had refused to eat voluntarily.<ref>Appel, Jacob M. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jacob-m-appel/beyond-guantanamo-torture_b_360082.html Beyond Guantanamo: Torture Thrives in Connecticut] November 17, 2009</ref> In 2009, terrorist [[Richard Reid (shoe bomber)|Richard Reid]], known as the "shoe bomber," was force-fed while on a hunger strike at the [[United States Penitentiary, Florence ADX]], the federal [[supermax]] prison in Colorado.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8094727.stm| publisher=BBC News| date=June 11, 2009 | title='Shoe bomber' is on hunger strike| accessdate=2009-03-10}}</ref> Hundreds of force-feedings have been reported at ADX Florence.<ref name="CleanHell">{{cite news|title =Supermax: A Clean Version Of Hell |publisher = [[CBS News]] |date = October 14, 2007 |url =http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/10/11/60minutes/main3357727.shtml |accessdate = 2009-05-31}}</ref> [[Ethel Byrne]] was the first female political prisoner in the United States to be subjected to force feeding <ref>{{cite book|last1=Lepore|first1=Jill|title=The Secret Life of Wonder Woman|date=2014|publisher=Alfred A. Knopf|location=New York|isbn=978-0-385-35404-2|page=95}}</ref> after she was jailed at Blackwell Island workhouse on January 22, 1917 for her activism in advocating for the legalization of [[birth control]]. She subsequently went on a [[hunger strike]] and refused to drink water for 185 hours. <ref>{{cite web|title=About Sanger|url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sanger/aboutms/organization_brownsville_clinic.php|website=Margaret Sanger Papers Project|publisher=MSPP|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref>
==== United Nations War Crimes Tribunal==== On December 6, 2006, the [[United Nations War Crimes Tribunal]] at [[The Hague]] approved the use of force-feeding of [[Serbia]]n politician [[Vojislav Šešelj]]. They decided it was not "torture, inhuman or degrading treatment if there is a medical necessity to do so... and if the manner in which the detainee is force-fed is not inhuman or degrading".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/yugo/article/0,,1966016,00.html | title=War crimes tribunal orders force-feeding of Serbian warlord | date=December 7, 2006 | publisher=The Guardian| accessdate = 2007-09-16 | location=London | first=Ian | last=Traynor}}</ref>
====Israel==== In 2015, the [[Knesset]] passed a law allowing the force-feeding of prisoners in response to a hunger strike by a Palestinian detainee who had been held for months in [[administrative detention]]. Israel doctors refused to feed Mohammad Allan against his will, and he resumed eating after the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Supreme Court]] temporarily released him.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2015/08/22/433587857/hunger-strike-raises-debate-about-force-feeding-in-israeli-prisons| title=Hunger Strike Raises Debate About Force-Feeding In Israeli Prisons |date=22 August 2015 }}</ref>
====Other forms==== Force-feeding of pernicious substances may be used as a form of [[torture]] and/or [[physical punishment]]. While in prison in northern Bosnia in 1996, some Serbian prisoners have described being forced to eat paper and soap.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/serb-prisoners-forced-to-eat-soap-during-months-of-beatings-in-solita-ry-confinement-1344790.html?printService=print |title= Serb prisoners 'forced to eat soap' during months of beatings in solitary confinement |work= [[The Independent]] |location=London |date= 30 March 1996 |first= Lynne Reid |last= Banks |authorlink= Lynne Reid Banks }}</ref>
Sometimes it has been alleged that prisoners are forced to eat foods forbidden by their religion. The ''[[Washington Post]]'' has reported that Muslim prisoners in [[Abu Ghraib prison]] under the [[History of Iraq (2003–2011)|U.S.-led coalition]] described in sworn statements having been forced to eat pork and drink alcohol, both of which are strictly [[haraam|forbidden in Islam]] (see [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse]]).<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A43783-2004May20.html | work=The Washington Post | title=New Details of Prison Abuse Emerge | date=2004-05-21}}</ref>
===Of babies=== [[File:'Gavage' method of infant feeding used in France. Wellcome L0001803.jpg|thumb|'Gavage' method of infant feeding used in France, late 19th century]] According to ''Infant feeding by artificial means: a scientific and practical treatise on the dietetics of infancy<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sadler|first1=S H|title=Infant feeding by artificial means: a scientific and practical treatise on the dietetics of infancy|date=1896|location=London|page=18|edition=2nd|accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>'', a French system of feeding newborn or premature babies who could not suckle was known as ''gavage''. Sadler dates its origin to 1874 and quotes [[Étienne Stéphane Tarnier]], a pioneer perinatologist, describing the procedure. <ref>{{cite book|last1=Sadler|first1=S H|date=1896|edition=2nd|accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>
===For girls before marriage=== {{Main|Leblouh}} Force-feeding used to be practiced in the [[North Africa]] and still is in [[Mauritania]]. Fatness was considered a marriage asset in women; culturally, [[voluptuous]] figures were perceived as indicators of wealth. In this tradition, some girls are forced by their mothers or grandmothers to overeat, often accompanied by [[physical punishment]] (e.g., pressing a finger between two pieces of wood) should the girl not eat. The intended result is a rapid onset of [[obesity]], and the practice may start at a young age and continue for years. This is still the tradition in the rather undernourished [[Sahel]] country [[Mauritania]] (where it is called [[leblouh]]), where it induces major health risks in the female population; some younger men no longer insist on voluptuous brides, but traditional beauty norms remain part of the culture.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/0711/p04s01-woaf.html "Women rethink a big size that is beautiful but brutal"] Clare Soares 11 July 2006. ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]''</ref><ref>[http://subalternate.wordpress.com/2008/08/17/gavage-in-mauritania/ "Gavage in Mauritania"] ''[Subalternate Reality]''</ref>
===In slavery=== Slaves who tried to [[suicide|commit suicide]] by starving themselves were force fed with a contraption called the ''speculum orum''. This device forced the slave's mouth open in order to be fed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/part1/1p277.html|title=Africans in America/Part 1/The Middle Passage|website=www.pbs.org|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>
== Of domestic animals == [[File:Hyena-forcefeed.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ancient Egyptian]] force-feeding a [[hyena]]]] Force-feeding has been used to prepare animals for slaughter. In some cases, such as is the case with geese raised for [[foie gras]], it is still practiced today.
=== In farming === {{Main|Foie gras}} [[Image:Mulard duck being force fed corn in order to fatten its liver for foie gras production.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Animal welfare]] groups object to force-feeding of birds. Here a [[Mulard duck]] is being force fed corn in order to fatten its liver for [[foie gras]] production.]] Force-feeding is also known as gavage, from a French word meaning "to gorge". This term specifically refers to force-feeding of [[Domestic duck|ducks]] or [[Domestic goose|geese]] in order to fatten their livers in the production of [[foie gras]]. In modern [[Egypt]], the practice of fattening geese and male [[Muscovy duck]]s by force-feeding{{dubious|date=May 2014|reason=Are you sure tubes are inserted in their mouths?! Over-feeding is different from force-feeding.}} them various grains is present, mostly by individuals, unrelated to foie gras production, but for general consumption of those birds later. It is not widespread on commercial farms however. The term used for such a practice is called "Tazgheet" تزغيط from the verb "Zaghghat" زغَط.
Force-feeding of birds is practiced mostly on geese or male [[Mulard|Moulard ducks]], a Muscovy/Pekin hybrid. Preparation for gavage usually begins 4–5 months before slaughter. For geese, after an initial free-range period and treatment to assist in esophagus dilation (eating grass, for example), the force-feeding commences. Gavage is performed 2–4 times a day for 2–5 weeks, depending on the size of the fowl, using a funnel attached to a slim metal or plastic feeding tube inserted into the bird's throat to deposit the food into the bird's [[crop (anatomy)|crop]] (the storage area in the esophagus). A grain mash, usually maize mixed with fats and vitamin supplements, is the feed of choice. Waterfowl are suited to the tube method due to a non-existent [[Vomiting|gag]] reflex and an extremely flexible esophagus, unlike other fowl such as [[chickens]]. These migratory waterfowl are also said to be ideal for gavage because of their natural ability to gain large amounts of weight in short periods of time before cold seasons.
[[Shen Dzu]] is a similar practice of force-feeding pigs.
===In scientific research=== Gavage is used in some scientific studies such as those involving the rate of metabolism. It is practiced upon various [[laboratory animal]]s, such as mice. Liquids such as medicines may be administered to the animals via a tube or syringe.<ref>http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v444/n7122/abs/nature05414.htmlAn obesity-associated gut microbiome with increased capacity for energy harvest</ref>

The '''Frog Boys''' ({{lang-ko|개구리소년}}''Gaegurisonyeon'') is a group of five murdered [[South Korea]]n boys who disappeared on March 26, 1991 while frog-hunting. Their bodies were found 11 years later.
The incident has been the subject of two films: ''Come Back, Frog Boys'' (1992)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://movie.naver.com/movie/bi/mi/photo.nhn?code=16103#ps|title=돌아오라 개구리 소년|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=Naver.com}}</ref> and ''[[Children (2011 film)|Children]]'' (2011). There are also several songs referencing the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1909080|title=Missing persons ignored|date=28 September 2002|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref>
==Victims== [[File:Frogboysphonecard.png|right|thumb|This phone card, with the photos of the boys, was used to raise awareness and help find them. In Western culture, the boys are one year younger than the ages listed here (due to [[East Asian age reckoning#Korean|Korean age reckoning]])]]
The five boys were between 9 and 13 years old:<ref name="bodiesfound">{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1909041|title=Bodies of 5 'frog boys,' missing since 1991, found on mountain|date=27 September 2002|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=JoongAng Daily|author=Hwang Sun-yoon}}</ref> *U Cheol-won (aged 13) *Jo Ho-yeon (aged 12) *Kim Yeong-gyu (aged 11) *Park Chan-in (aged 10) *Kim Jong-sik (aged 9)
==Circumstances and disappearance== March 26, 1991 was a public holiday in South Korea for the [[South Korean local elections, 1991|1991 local elections]]. The boys decided to spend the day catching frogs in the streams of Mount Waryong ({{Coord|35.867|N|128.513|E|display=inline}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=102&oid=001&aid=0003538117|title=실종국교생 5명 3일째 행방묘연|date=28 March 1991|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=Yeonhap News}}</ref> They never returned to their homes.
After they were reported missing, their story became a national sensation. President [[Roh Tae-woo]] sent 300,000 police and military troops to search for the missing boys,<ref name="bodiesfound" /> with the searches shown on live TV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2932030|title=Fictional resolution mars movie about unsolved murder|date=11 February 2011|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=JoongAng Daily}}</ref> Several of the boys' parents left their jobs to travel around the country, looking for their children.<ref name="bodiesfound" /> Mount Waryong was searched over 500 times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-26101686_ITM|title=After Discovery of Taegu Remains, Cause of Death Still Uncertain|date=28 September 2011|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=Korea Times}}</ref>
==Discovery of bodies== On September 26, 2002, a man searching for acorns discovered their bodies in the mountain, an area that had been previously searched. He first reported the remains via an anonymous phone call.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2002092899618|title=Police Continue Excavation, Find Loaded Shell Near the Site|date=27 September 2002|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=Dong-A Ilbo|author=Sung-Kyu Kim}}</ref> Initially, the police stated that they thought the boys had died of [[hypothermia]]. However, the parents did not accept that conclusion and demanded a full investigation.<ref name="bodiesfound" /> The families questioned the conclusion that the boys had simply died after getting lost due to the oddities of the boys' clothes being found tied in knots and of their bodies being found a short distance from the village in an area the boys knew very well.<ref name="Hwang Sun-yoon">{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1909669|title='Frog boys' baffle investigators|date=11 October 2002|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=JoongAng Daily|author=Hwang Sun-yoon}}</ref> Forensic experts discovered that the boys had been murdered with repeated blows to the head<ref>{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1911052|title='Frog boys' probably murdered|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=JoongAng Daily|date=13 November 2002|author=Hwang Sun-yoon}}</ref> and that one had been shot in the head with a [[shotgun]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2002/11/12/2002111261033.html|title='Frog Boys' Concluded as Murdered |date=12 November 2002|publisher=Chosun Ilbo|accessdate=15 July 2011|author=Keum Won-seob}}</ref>
==Aftermath== In 2006, the [[statute of limitations]] expired on the case. This means authorities cannot prosecute anyone for the murders.<ref name="statuteoflimitations">{{Cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2006/03/24/2006032461036.html|title=Statute Runs Out for Unsolved 'Frog Boys' Murder|date=24 March 2006|accessdate=15 July 2011|publisher=Chosun Daily|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120910053015/http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2006/03/24/2006032461036.html|archive-date=2012-09-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The police said they will continue the investigation to get answers.<ref name="statuteoflimitations" />

Myers]], [[Florida]], February 11, 1929.]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-12257, Harvey Firestone.jpg|thumb|200px|Firestone in 1931]] '''Harvey Samuel Firestone''' (December 20, 1868 – February 7, 1938) was an American businessman, and the founder of the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]], one of the first global makers of automobile tires. ==Family background== Firestone was born on the [[Columbiana, Ohio]] farm built by his paternal grandfather. He was the second of Benjamin and Catherine ([[née]] Flickinger) Firestone's three sons; Benjamin had a son and a daughter by his first wife. The original farm was disassembled and moved to [[Greenfield Village]], a {{convert|90|acre|m2|adj=on}} historical site founded by [[Henry Ford]], in 1983 as part of a larger outdoor museum. Firestone's paternal great-great-great-grandfather, Hans Nicholas Feuerstein, immigrated from [[Berg, Bas-Rhin]], [[France]],[http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/f/r/a/Scott-O-Fraser/FILE/0022page.html Familytreemaker.genealogy.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212063747/http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/f/r/a/Scott-O-Fraser/FILE/0022page.html |date=2012-02-12 }} in 1753, and settled in [[Pennsylvania]].[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p1670.htm "Shirer Family Genealogy Project, Person Page 1670" ''ancestry.com''] October 18, 2010 Three of Nicholas' sons – including Harvey's great-great-grandfather, Johan Nicholas – changed their surname to "Firestone", the English translation of the family's German name "Feuerstein".[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p1687.htm "Shirer Family Genealogy Project, Person Page 1687" ''ancestry.com''] October 18, 2010 On November 20, 1895, Firestone married [[Idabelle Smith Firestone|Idabelle Smith]].[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p11749.htm "Shirer Family Genealogy Project, Person Page 11733" ''ancestry.com''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102191137/http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p11749.htm |date=2012-11-02 }} October 18, 2010 They eventually had seven children. Notable great-grandchildren include: [[Andrew Firestone]], [[Nick Firestone]], and [[William Clay Ford, Jr.]] (the son of Henry Ford's grandson and Harvey and Idabelle's granddaughter [[Martha Firestone Ford|Martha]]). ==Education and career== After graduating from [[Columbiana High School]], Firestone worked for the [[Columbus Buggy Company]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]] before starting his own company in 1890, making [[rubber]] tires for [[carriage]]s. In 1900 he soon saw the huge potential for marketing tires for automobiles and then founded the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]], a pioneer in the mass production of tires. In 1926 he published a book, ''Men and Rubber: The Story of Business'', which was written in collaboration with [[Samuel Crowther (journalist)|Samuel Crowther]].''Men and Rubber: The Story of Business''. By Harvey Samuel Firestone, in collaboration with [[Samuel Crowther (journalist)|Samuel Crowther]]. London: William Heinemann & Co., printed in U.S.A., 1926. ==Death== In 1938, Firestone died of [[coronary thrombosis]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Harvey Firestone is Dead in Florida. Rubber Manufacturer Dies in Sleep at His Miami Beach Estate. He Was 69 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1938/02/08/archives/harvey-firestone-is-dead-in-florida-rubber-manufacturer-dies-in.html |quote=Harvey S. Firestone, a farm boy who built one of the largest rubber businesses in the world, died of a coronary thrombosis as he slept early today in the great mansion of Harbel Villa, an ocean-front estate he acquired in 1924. He was 69 years old. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=February 8, 1938}} ==The Millionaires' Club== Firestone, [[Henry Ford]], and [[Thomas Edison]] were generally considered the three leaders in American industry at the time, and often worked and vacationed together.{{cite web |last=Zumbrun |first=Francis Champ |title=Famous Travelers - Edison, Ford and Firestone |publisher=Maryland Department of Natural Resources |url=http://www.dnr.state.md.us/feature_stories/FamousTravelersPart1.asp |accessdate=February 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203060801/http://www.dnr.state.md.us/feature_stories/FamousTravelersPart1.asp |archivedate=February 3, 2013 |df= }} All three were part of a very exclusive group titled "The Millionaires' Club." ==Legacy== The main library of [[Princeton University]] is named [[Firestone Library]] in his honor. It is among the largest university libraries in the world. On August 3, 1950, the [[Harvey S Firestone Memorial]], a large sculpture ensemble dedicated to Firestone, created by sculptors [[James Earle Fraser (sculptor)|James Earle Fraser]] and [[Donald De Lue]] was dedicated. It is located at Bridgestone Firestone Inc., 1200 Firestone Parkway in [[Akron, Ohio]]. In 1974, Firestone was inducted into the [[Automotive Hall of Fame]]. [[Firestone High School]] in [[Akron, Ohio]], is named in his honor. There is a Harvey S Firestone Park in [[Columbiana, Ohio]]. The town [[Harbel]] in [[Liberia]], home to Firestone's rubber plantation, the largest in the world, is named after Firestone and his wife Isabelle. ==See also== * [[Firestone Stadium]] * [[Harvey S. Firestone Memorial]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.firestone.com/ Firestone Tires] *[http://www.bridgestoneamericas.com/corporate/history/index.html Firestone Tires' History] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140714163621/http://btr360.com/2014/07/01/22-business-ideas-from-harvey-firestone/ Harvey Firestone: Where the Rubber Meets the Road] *{{IMDb name|id=1304843|name=Harvey Firestone}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060928175459/http://www.academyofachievement.org/honorees/harvey_firestone.htm Academy of Achievement's biography on Firestone] *[http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/people/A0818742.html Info Please biography on Harvey Firestone] *[http://www.nndb.com/people/788/000086530/ NNDB biography on Harvey Firestone] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060830081312/http://www.automotivehalloffame.org/honors/index.php?cmd=view&id=58&type=inductees Automotive Hall of Fame biography on Harvey Firestone] *[http://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/205/301/ic/cdc/industrial/firestone.htm About Firestone Canada] *[http://firestone1753.weebly.com/ Firestone Roots in Alsace] *{{findagrave|grid=339}} * {{PM20|FID=pe/005196}} {{Bridgestone Corporation}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Firestone, Harvey}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Firestone family]] [[Category:People from Columbiana, Ohio]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Akron, Ohio]] [[Category:Tire industry people]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]] [[Category:Henry Ford family]] [[Category:Automotive pioneers]] [[Category:American people of French descent]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:American people of Austrian descent]] [[Category:Asheville School alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from coronary thrombosis]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{use South African English|date=May 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Reduced pull quote|right|During my lifetime I have dedicated my life to this struggle of the African people. I have fought against white domination, and I have fought against black domination. I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons will live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. It is an ideal for which I hope to live for and to see realised. But, My Lord, if it needs be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die.|[[Nelson Mandela]]|at the conclusion of his speech<ref>{{cite web|last=Mandela|first=Nelson|title=I am prepared to die|url=http://db.nelsonmandela.org/speeches/pub_view.asp?pg=item&ItemID=NMS010|work=Nelson Mandela Centre of Memory|publisher=Nelson Mandela Foundation|accessdate=16 December 2013}}</ref>}}
"'''I Am Prepared to Die'''" is the name given<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.historyplace.com/speeches/mandela.htm |title=The History Place – Great Speeches Collection: Nelson Mandela Speech – I am Prepared to Die |first= |last= |work=historyplace.com |year=2012 |accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref> to the three-hour speech given by [[Nelson Mandela]] on 20 April 1964 from the dock of the defendant at the [[Rivonia Trial]]. The speech is so titled because it ends with the words "it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die". The speech is considered one of the great speeches of the 20th century, and a key moment in the history of South African democracy.<ref>{{cite book|title=Speeches that Changed the World|editor=Owen Collins|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0664221492}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Drawing the line: towards an aesthetics of transnational justice|first=Carrol|last=Clarkson|publisher=Fordham University Press|pages=84–86|year=2014|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TWsGAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA85|isbn=9780823254156}}</ref>
==The trial== {{Main|Rivonia Trial}}
In July 1963, ten [[African National Congress]] (ANC) leaders were arrested in [[Rivonia]], a suburb of Johannesburg. Along with Mandela, who had been arrested in August 1962 and was serving a five-year sentence, they were accused of counts of sabotage, furthering communism and aiding foreign powers. This included charges of recruiting persons to undertake guerrilla warfare against the South African state, conspiring to aid foreign military against the republic, and furthering acts of communism. The prosecutor [[Percy Yutar]] did not explicitly move for the death penalty, but it was generally believed that that was what the state wanted.<ref>{{cite book|title=Rivonia's Children: Three Families and the Cost of Conscience in White South Africa|first=Glenn|last=Frankel|publisher=Jacana Media|year=2011|page=258}}</ref> All defendants pleaded not guilty to the charges.<ref name=SAHistory2>{{cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/topic/rivonia-trial-1963-1964|title=Rivonia Trial 1963–64|publisher=Sahistory.org.za |date= |accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref>
Before the trial Mandela and the other defendants decided that instead of testifying as witnesses and submitting to cross-examination he would make a speech from the dock to put the state on trial, by pointing out the injustices of the South African society and its legal system. They also sought to show the political and moral programme of the ANC.<ref name="Mandela 2008">{{cite book|title=[[Long Walk to Freedom]]|first=Nelson|last=Mandela|year=2008|isbn=978-0316548182|authorlink=Nelson Mandela}}</ref>
Mandela worked on the speech for weeks before the trial, receiving help in editing and polishing it from author [[Nadine Gordimer]] and journalist [[Anthony Sampson]].<ref name=Frankel>{{cite news|title=The Speech at Rivonia Trial that Changed History|author=Glen Frankel|date=5 December 2013|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/when-mandelas-and-the-worlds-fate-changed-at-historic-rivonia-trial/2013/12/05/22033836-5e10-11e3-be07-006c776266ed_story.html}}</ref> In writing the speech, Mandela was inspired by [[Fidel Castro]]'s famous "[[History Will Absolve Me]]" defence speech. He was particularly interested in making the speech appeal to an international audience, inspiring international support for the ANC cause.<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Mandela: The Authorized Biography]]|first=Anthony|last=Sampson|publisher=Random House LLC|year=2012}}</ref>
Mandela's lawyers urged him to leave out the final statement, lest it provoke the judge into sentencing him to death, but Mandela refused. He felt that he was likely to be sentenced to death regardless of his statement, so that saying what he truly felt would be the best option.<ref name="Mandela 2008"/> Nonetheless, he did add the qualifier "if it needs be".<ref name=LeRoux>{{cite book|title=Precedent & Possibility: The (ab)use of Law in South Africa|first=Dennis|last=Davis|first2=Michelle |last2=Le Roux|publisher=Juta and Company Ltd|isbn=9781770130227| year=2009|pages=48–50}}</ref>
When the defence announced that Mandela would begin by giving a speech instead of facing a more traditional cross-examination the prosecutor Percy Yutar made a surprised objection: "My Lord, My Lord, I think you should warn the accused that what he said from the dock has far less weight than if he submitted himself to cross-examination."<ref name=LeRoux/> Judge de Wet over-ruled the objection saying, "I think Mr. Yutar, that counsel for the defence have sufficient experience to be able to advise their clients without your assistance." And [[Bram Fischer]] the main defence lawyer added "Neither we, nor our clients are unaware of the provisions of the Criminal Code", in this way subtly pointing out the fact that Mandela was himself a lawyer with experience in criminal trials.<ref>{{cite book|title=The State Vs. Nelson Mandela: The Trial That Changed South Africa|first=Joel|last=Joffe|publisher=Oneworld|year=2007|pages=154–55}}</ref> Since in South African law a defendant may not address the court from the witness stand, but only answer questions, Mandela gave the speech from the defendant's dock. He spoke for some three hours, before concluding with the often quoted passage "I am prepared to die".
While delivering the last line of the speech Mandela looked the judge, [[Quartus de Wet]] directly in the eye, the last eye contact between the two during the trial.<ref name=SAHistory>{{cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/topic/rivonia-trial-fifty-years-later |title=The Rivonia Trial Fifty Years later | South African History Online |publisher=Sahistory.org.za |date= |accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref>
==The speech== The speech describes why the ANC had decided to go beyond its previous use of constitutional methods and Gandhian non-violent resistance, and adopt sabotage against property (designed to minimise risks of injury and death) as a part of their activism against the South African government and its [[Apartheid]] policies (while also training a military wing for possible future use).
Mandela began by stating that he had been among the founders of [[Umkhonto we Sizwe]], the armed wing of the ANC, and that he did not deny his involvement in planning sabotage, saying "I did not plan it in a spirit of recklessness, nor because I have any love for violence. I planned it as a result of a calm and sober assessment of the political situation that had arisen after many years of tyranny, [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]], and oppression of my people by the whites."<ref name=Broun/>
Mandela argued that all non-violent means had been tried and that they had only resulted in mounting restrictions and reduced freedom for the African people. Referring to the [[Sharpeville massacre|Sharpeville shootings]] and a number of other instances of government violence against protesters, he stated that "the government which uses force to support its rule teaches the oppressed to use force to oppose it", and that the decision to adopt selective use of violent means was "not because we desire such a course. Solely because the government left us no other choice."<ref name=LeRoux/>
Mandela also devoted significant effort to refuting the prosecution's charges that he and the ANC had acted under the domination of the [[Communist Party of South Africa]] and foreign interests. He likened the alliance between the communists and the ANC to the alliance of the US, Britain and the Soviet Union against Nazi Germany. He discussed in some detail the relationship between the ANC and the Communist Party, explaining that, while the two shared a commitment to action against the apartheid system, he was wedded to a model of [[constitutional democracy]] for South Africa (he singled out the British political model for particular praise), and also supported a market economy rather than a communist economic model. He noted that, while there were political differences between the Communists and the ANC, "theoretical differences among those fighting against oppression is (sic) a luxury that we cannot afford at this stage". He added that the communists had been the only political group in South Africa who had shown themselves willing to treat Africans as human beings.<ref name=Broun/> {{Nelson Mandela series}} ===Impact=== Mandela's friends [[Anthony Sampson]] and [[Nadine Gordimer]], who had both participated in reviewing the speech as written by Mandela,<ref>{{cite web|title=NPW|url=http://www.digitalnpq.org/articles/global/705/04-18-2014/nadine_gordimer|publisher=New Perspectives Quartely}}</ref> had contrasting reactions to its delivery. Sampson described it as the most effective speech of his career, whereas Gordimer thought the delivery to be "hesitant, parsonical" until "only at the end did the man come through and when he had spoken that last sentence the strangest and most moving sound I have ever heard from human throats, came from the 'black' side of the court audience" .<ref name=LeRoux/>
At the end of the trial Mandela was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment. He served 27 years of the sentence before he was released and elected [[President of South Africa]]. Upon his release he quoted the last sentence of his speech to the awaiting press.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Penguin Book of Twentieth-century Speeches|first=Brian |last=MacArthur|publisher=Viking|year=1994|page=467}}</ref> Mandela believed that the reason Judge de Wet had not sentenced him to death was because, by his speech, Mandela had "dared him to do so".<ref name=Broun>{{cite book|last=Broun|first=K. S. |year=2012|title=Saving Nelson Mandela: The Rivonia Trial and the Fate of South Africa|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=74–75}}</ref> ==Influence== *The "I am prepared to die" sentence was used by South African composer Michael Hankinson in his 2004 orchestral work "A Mandela Portrait" as the choral finale of the first movement.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Blake|first=M.|year=2005|title=The present-day composer refuses to budge: Case studies in new South African orchestral music|journal=South African Journal of Musicology|volume=25|pages=127–143|url=http://www.michaelblake.co.za/sites/default/files/the-present-day-composer-refuses-to-budge-by-michael-blake.pdf}}</ref> *The last paragraph of the speech is written on the wall of South Africa's [[Constitutional Court of South Africa|Constitutional Court]] building in Johannesburg.<ref name=Broun/> *US President [[Barack Obama]] quoted from the speech during his tribute speech at the [[Death and state funeral of Nelson Mandela#State memorial service|state memorial service for Nelson Mandela]] held at [[FNB Stadium]] in Johannesburg on 10 December 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Obama's tribute to Mandela: The full speech|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-12-10-obamas-tribute-to-mandela-the-full-speech|accessdate=11 December 2013|newspaper=Mail & Guardian|date=10 December 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{wikisource|Nelson Mandela's statement from the dock at the Rivonia Trial}} *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2013/dec/05/nelson-mandela-1964-speech-audio Audio recording of the speech]
