page.title: International reaction to the assassination of Benazir Bhutto

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 2 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Benazir Bhutto sidebar}} The '''international reaction to the [[assassination of Benazir Bhutto|assassination of]]''' '''[[Benazir Bhutto]]''' consisted of universal condemnation across the [[international community]],<ref name=BBCReaction/> including Pakistan's regional neighbors [[Afghanistan]], [[China]], [[India]], [[Bangladesh]], and [[Iran]]. Indian [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Manmohan Singh]] praised Bhutto's efforts for the improvement of [[India-Pakistan relations]]. The [[UN Security Council]] held an emergency meeting and unanimously condemned the assassination, a call echoed by [[UN Secretary General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]]. Both [[European Union]] [[President of the European Commission|President]] [[José Manuel Barroso]] and U.S. [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] also expressed the hope that Pakistan will continue on the path of democracy.
== Africa == *{{ALG}} – The Foreign Ministry issued a statement, saying that "Algeria is keen to condemn with the greatest firmness this criminal act, which came to shatter the fate of an exceptional personality, fully involved in the democratic fight for the renewal of her country."<ref>{{cite news|title=Algeria condemns assassination of Benazir Bhutto|url=http://www.aps.dz/an/pageview.asp?ID=180536|archive-url=https://archive.is/20080102051154/http://www.aps.dz/an/pageview.asp?ID=180536|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-01-02|publisher=Algeria Press Service|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{EGY}} – [[Foreign Minister of Egypt|Foreign Minister]] [[Ahmed Aboul Gheit]] "conveyed deep condolences to the bereaved family of Benazir Bhutto, her party workers, government and people of Pakistan.."<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt condemns Benazir's assassination |url=http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=24659&Itemid=2 |publisher=Associated Press (APP) |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103050125/http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=24659&Itemid=2 |archivedate=2008-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{LBR}} – [[President of Liberia|President]] [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] released a statement, saying that she was "deeply disturbed and saddened by the events in Pakistan."<ref>{{cite news|title=President Sirleaf Saddened by Bhutto's Assassination |url=http://www.liberianobserver.com/news/fullstory.php/aid/9835/President_Sirleaf_Saddened_by_Bhutto's_Assassination.html |publisher=Liberian Observer |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103000541/http://www.liberianobserver.com/news/fullstory.php/aid/9835/President_Sirleaf_Saddened_by_Bhutto%27s_Assassination.html |archivedate=2008-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{flag|Libya|1977}} – The [[Foreign ministers of Libya|Foreign Ministry]] released a statement condemning the "odious terrorist operation" and affirming its "staunch opposition to all that is likely to jeopardize security and peace in Pakistani society".<ref>{{cite news|title=Libya condemns assassination of Benazir Bhutto|url=http://www.afriquenligne.fr/news/daily-news/libya-condemns-assassination-of-benazir-bhutto-2007122814080/|publisher=Afriquenligne|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103030648/http://www.afriquenligne.fr/news/daily-news/libya-condemns-assassination-of-benazir-bhutto-2007122814080/|archive-date=2008-01-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *{{MAR}} – [[List of rulers of Morocco|King]] [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|Mohammed VI]] condemned the assassination in a message to Musharraf, describing Bhutto as "one of illustrious leaders [of Pakistan] both in the Government and in the opposition."<ref>{{cite news|first=Mudassir|last=Rizwan|title=Moroccan King condemns killing of Benazir Bhutto|url=http://www.indianmuslims.info/news/2007/dec/27/moroccan_king_condemns_killing_benazir_bhutto.html|publisher=Indian Muslims|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2007-12-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102042452/http://www.indianmuslims.info/news/2007/dec/27/moroccan_king_condemns_killing_benazir_bhutto.html|archivedate=2008-01-02|df=}}</ref> *{{NAM}} – A Foreign Affairs Ministry statement called on the Pakistani authorities to "ensure that those who have carried this pre-meditated and cowardly killing are brought to justice." It also offered condolences to the families of Bhutto and those who were killed in the blast.<ref>{{cite news|title=BHUTTO |url=http://www.nbc.com.na/news/today.php?newsid=1436 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102051348/http://www.nbc.com.na/news/today.php?newsid=1436 |archivedate=2008-01-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{NGR}} – [[President of Nigeria|President]] [[Umaru Yar'Adua]] urged Bhutto's family, the Pakistani government and her supporters "to take solace in the knowledge that she died in active pursuit of her vision of true democracy for her country, and that in death, she has become an eternal martyr to the cause she believed in with all her heart."<ref>{{cite news |title=Nigerian president condemns Bhutto assassination |url=http://www.africasia.com/services/news/newsitem.php?area=africa&item=071228081153.kzfuahl7.php |publisher=IC Publications |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{RSA}} – [[Department of Foreign Affairs (South Africa)|Foreign Affairs]] spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa said, "Clearly South Africa is saddened by the news of the murder of Benazir Bhutto and condemns unequivocally this outrageous act of violence...We call on the Pakistani people do everything in their power, to leave no stone unturned to find the perpetrators of this dastardly act."<ref>{{cite news |title=Bhutto: Reactions from around the world |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/459/603880 |publisher=New Vision Online |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107071136/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/459/603880 |archivedate=2008-01-07 |df= }}</ref> *{{TUN}} – The Foreign Affairs Ministry released a statement that strongly denounced the assassination, expressing "regret over the Pakistani official's slaying."<ref>{{cite news |title = Tunisia deplores slaying of benazir bhutto |url = http://english.bna.bh/?ID=65485 |accessdate = 2007-12-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080102225617/http://english.bna.bh/?ID=65485 |archivedate = 2008-01-02 |df = }}</ref> *{{UGA}} – [[Politics of Uganda#Ministries of Uganda|Foreign Affairs Minister]] Isaac Musumba said, "It is very deplorable and very pathetic. We thought that democracy was finally having its day in Pakistan. The murder of Bhutto and other people shows that terrorism must continue to be fought relentlessly and without compromise."<ref>{{cite news|title = Uganda condemns Bhutto assassination|url = http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/603846|accessdate = 2007-12-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071230000733/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/603846|archivedate = 2007-12-30|df = }}</ref>
== Asia == *{{AFG}} – [[President of Afghanistan|President]] [[Hamid Karzai]] condemned "the act of cowardice and immense brutality in the strongest possible terms." He praised Bhutto for "having sacrificed her life for the sake of Pakistan and for the sake of this region."<ref name=BBCReaction>{{cite news |title=Reactions to Bhutto assassination |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7161660.stm |publisher=BBC |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> *{{BHR}} – The government denounced the assassination, saying that "[it] extends its sincere condolences to Bhutto's family and all the Pakistani people" and calling for "self-restraint."<ref>{{cite news |title = Bahrain condemns Bhutto assassination |url = http://english.bna.bh/?ID=65476 |accessdate = 2007-12-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080102223203/http://english.bna.bh/?ID=65476 |archivedate = 2008-01-02 |df = }}</ref> *{{BAN}} – [[Prime Minister of Bangladesh|Prime Minister]] [[Fakhruddin Ahmed]] condemned the attack, stating that "it was an unpardonable crime that has shocked the world. The government and people of Bangladesh mourned this tragedy with their Pakistani brethren." Major political parties also condemned the assassination. The [[Awami League]] urged "pro-democratic and progressive forces to stand united against this heinous killing", while the [[Bangladesh Nationalist Party]] feared the assassination may leave "an adverse impact on the democratic politics of the subcontinent". The [[Jatiya Party (Ershad)|Jatiya Party]], [[Workers Party of Bangladesh]], [[National Awami Party]] and [[Bikalpa Dhara Bangladesh]] also issued statements of strong condemnation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=16826 |title=Dhaka condemns assassination |publisher=Thedailystar.net |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2010-08-06}}</ref> *{{BRU}} - [[List of Sultans of Brunei|Sultan]] [[Hassanal Bolkiah]] "expressed shock" and condemned Bhutto's assassination. He also conveyed his deepest condolences and profound respects to the people of Pakistan and to the family and friends of the late Benazir Bhutto.<ref>{{cite news |title=Royal condolences to Pakistan |url=http://www.bt.com.bn/en/home_news/2007/12/29/royal_condolences_to_pakistan |publisher=The Brunei Times |date=2007-12-29 |accessdate=2007-12-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101095323/http://www.bt.com.bn/en/home_news/2007/12/29/royal_condolences_to_pakistan |archivedate=2008-01-01 |df= }}</ref> *{{KHM}} - [[Prime Minister of Cambodia|Prime Minister]] [[Hun Sen]] condemned the assassination, calling it "coward terrorism", and said that her killing was "a serious problem in Pakistan". He also expressed his condolences to Bhutto's family and called for all political parties in Pakistan to solve matters patiently.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cambodia Condemns Assassination Of Bhutto |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/28/content_7329824.htm |publisher=Xinhua |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104114138/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/28/content_7329824.htm |archivedate=January 4, 2008 }}</ref> *{{CHN}} – A [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Foreign Ministry]] spokesperson Qin Gang said that China was "shocked at the killing of Pakistan's opposition leader Benazir Bhutto" and "strongly condemns the terrorist attack."<ref name="Global outrage over assassination">{{cite news|title=Global outrage over assassination |publisher=Al-Jazeera |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E933FBE1-6592-4764-A41F-17762EA7ABF8.htm |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071228205955/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E933FBE1-6592-4764-A41F-17762EA7ABF8.htm |archivedate=2007-12-28 |df= }}</ref> *{{IND}} – [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Manmohan Singh]] said he was "deeply shocked and horrified to hear of the heinous assassination of Mrs. Benazir Bhutto. Mrs. Bhutto was no ordinary political leader, but one who left a deep imprint on her time and age. Her contributions to a previous moment of hope in [[Indo-Pakistani relations|India–Pakistan relations]], and her intent to break India Pakistan relations out of the sterile patterns of the past, were exemplary. In her death, the South Asia has lost an outstanding leader who worked for democracy and reconciliation in her country. The manner of her going is a reminder of the common dangers that our region faces from cowardly acts of terrorism and of the need to eradicate this dangerous threat. My heartfelt condolences go to her family and the people of Pakistan who have suffered a grievous blow." [[Indian Foreign Minister|Foreign Minister]] [[Pranab Mukherjee]] said he "heard with shock and horror of the death of Mrs. Benazir Bhutto," whose "contributions to democracy, to the improvement of India–Pakistan relations, and to the restoration of normalcy within Pakistan will be an inspiration. Mrs. Bhutto was a brave and outstanding woman leader of the South Asia. That she should fall to a barbarous terrorist attack is particularly tragic, and should strengthen our resolve to fight this scourge."<ref name=BBCReaction /><ref>{{cite news|first=Nilova|last=Roy|title=India expresses shock, horror at Bhutto's assassination|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/FullcoverageStoryPage.aspx?id=481be59c-a0d8-4224-b0ce-5a5a0fc97fb2Benazirassassinated_Special&MatchID1=4625&TeamID1=1&TeamID2=6&MatchType1=1&SeriesID1=1165&MatchID2=4617&TeamID3=3&TeamID4=4&MatchType2=1&SeriesID2=1163&PrimaryID=4625&Headline=India+expresses+shock%2c+horror|publisher=Hindustan Times|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230184326/http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/FullcoverageStoryPage.aspx?id=481be59c-a0d8-4224-b0ce-5a5a0fc97fb2Benazirassassinated_Special&MatchID1=4625&TeamID1=1&TeamID2=6&MatchType1=1&SeriesID1=1165&MatchID2=4617&TeamID3=3&TeamID4=4&MatchType2=1&SeriesID2=1163&PrimaryID=4625&Headline=India+expresses+shock%2C+horror|archivedate=2007-12-30|df=}}</ref> *{{INA}} – [[President of Indonesia|President]] [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] said, "...he was shocked and condemned the terrorists". He expressed a hope that such a fatal accident will not harm democracy in Pakistan, which is now unstable especially towards its general elections which will be held on January 15, 2008. He also said that "the incident had dealt a serious blow to the transition of democracy."<ref>{{cite news|title=President Yudhoyono shocked after hearing Benazir Bhutto's death|url=http://www.antara.co.id/en/arc/2007/12/28/president-yudhoyono-shocked-after-hearing-benazir-bhuttos-death/|date=2007-12-28|publisher=Antara|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231132500/http://www.antara.co.id/en/arc/2007/12/28/president-yudhoyono-shocked-after-hearing-benazir-bhuttos-death/|archivedate=2007-12-31|df=}}</ref> *{{IRN}} – [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Foreign Minister]], [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] expressed the deep sympathy of the Iranian nation and government and said he hoped that the Pakistani government would try and track down the culprits behind this crime against Bhutto and a number of innocent people who were present at the scene when a gunman fatally shot her and set off a bomb.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iranian FM strongly condemns Bhutto's assassination|url=http://www2.irna.ir/en/news/view/line-22/0712288630100921.htm/|publisher=irna|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2007-12-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102074945/http://www2.irna.ir/en/news/view/line-22/0712288630100921.htm/|archivedate=2008-01-02|df=}}</ref> A [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Foreign Affairs Ministry]] spokesman [[Mohammad Ali Hosseini]] said that "we hope the Pakistani government will identify and bring to justice those behind such a criminal act and restore tranquility to the country," and that "the Pakistan government should use all efforts to identify the terrorist group which caused this incident and punish them to prevent terrorist groups from finding opportunities to undertake such actions again."<ref name=BBCReaction /><ref name = "cnn"/> *{{flag|Iraq|2004}} – [[President of Iraq|President]] [[Jalal Talabani]] called on the world to unite against the "cancer of terrorism".<ref>{{cite news|title=Global fears for Pakistan after Bhutto assassination|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5g99BnCtpvk73y01Shb7SNbAIsckw|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2007-12-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231140156/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5g99BnCtpvk73y01Shb7SNbAIsckw|archivedate=2007-12-31|df=}}</ref> *{{ISR}} – [[President of Israel|President]] [[Shimon Peres]] praised Bhutto, saying "[she] was a brave woman who did not conceal her opinions, knew no fear, and served her nation with unusual bravery and ability. She was an immeasurably charismatic leader and a warrior for peace in her land and all the world."<ref name=BBCReaction/><ref>{{cite news|first=Aviram|last=Zino|title=Benazir Bhutto assassinated| url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3487466,00.html|publisher=ynetnews.com |date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> President Peres hailed Bhutto as a "courageous woman" and said he was "shocked" by the news of her assassination.<ref>{{cite news|first=Barak|last=Ravid|title=Bush: Bhutto slaying 'cowardly'; Peres says 'shocked' by attack|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/939106.html|publisher=Haaretz.com|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[Deputy leaders of Israel|Deputy]] and [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Tzipi Livni]] issued the following statement: "We convey our condolences to the people of Pakistan and to the families of the victims. Benazir Bhutto was a well-known leader in Pakistan and in the international community who demonstrated brave leadership for her people. Israel expresses the hope that Pakistan will continue along the path of reconciliation, moderation and democracy."<ref>{{cite news|title=Israel condemns assassination of Benazir Bhutto|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/About+the+Ministry/MFA+Spokesman/2007/Israel+condemns+assassination+of+Benazir+Bhutto+27-Dec-2007.htm|publisher=mfa.gov.il|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> [[Israel Ambassador to the United Nations|Ambassador to the United Nations]] [[Dan Gillerman]] said that in the weeks prior to her assassination, Bhutto had expressed fear of being killed by extremist elements in Pakistan in emails she sent to him.<ref>{{cite news|first=Tali|last=Rabinovsky|title=Gillerman: Bhutto told me she feared for her life|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3487651,00.html|publisher=ynetnews.com|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> *{{JPN}} – [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Masahiko Kōmura]] condemned the attack, saying that "it is absolutely unacceptable to try to solve something by the means of violence."<ref name=BBCReaction/> *{{JOR}} – [[List of kings of Jordan|King]] [[Abdullah II of Jordan|Abdullah II]], in a message to Musharraf, condemned the assassination and expressed Jordan's "support to Pakistan" to overcome the consequences of this incident.<ref>{{cite news|title = Jordan's king condemns Bhutto killing|url =http://www.individual.com/story.php?story=75439281|accessdate = 2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{KUW}} – [[Politics of Kuwait#Ministries|Cabinet Affairs Minister]] Faisal Mohammad Al-Hajji said, "The State of Kuwait strongly condemns the vicious terrorist act which targeted the convoy of Mrs. Benazir Bhutto", and also said that Kuwait expresses sympathies for families of Bhutto and all those who were killed.<ref>{{cite news|title = Kuwait strongly condemns Bhutto''s assassination |url =http://www.kuna.net.kw/NewsAgenciesPublicSite/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=1870980&Language=en|accessdate = 2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{LIB}} – [[List of Prime Ministers of Lebanon|Prime Minister]] [[Fouad Siniora]] said that "Lebanon was shocked by the news of the assassination of former Prime Minister and leader of the Pakistan People's Party Ms. Benazir Bhutto", adding that "on behalf of the Lebanese people we denounce, condemn and deplore the assassination."<ref>{{cite news |title = Lebanon shocked by news of Bhutto' assassination |url = http://yalibnan.com/site/archives/2007/12/the_world_loses.php |accessdate = 2007-12-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071230084714/http://yalibnan.com/site/archives/2007/12/the_world_loses.php |archivedate = 2007-12-30 |df = }}</ref> *{{MAS}} – [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Prime Minister]] [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]] extended his deepest condolences to the families of Bhutto and the others who were killed. He also said, "The resort to extremism and violence is unacceptable and cannot be tolerated anywhere at any time. The perpetrators must be brought to justice." He added, "I hope the people in Pakistan will remain calm and I pray that the situation in Pakistan will soon stabilise."<ref>{{cite news |title=Abdullah Condemns Killing Of Benazir Bhutto |url=http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v3/news.php?id=304804 |publisher=Bernama |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
*{{MDV}} - [[President of Maldives|President]] [[Maumoon Abdul Gayoom]] condemned the attack and extended his condolences to the Pakistani Government, citizens and the families of Bhutto and the others who were killed. He said, " The government and people of the Maldives join me in extending our heartfelt sympathy to you, and your Government and to the brotherly people of Pakistan, at this time of distress and sorrow. Mrs. Bhutto had served Pakistan for many years, and during her years as Prime Minister, played an important role in regional and world affairs. She was also a very good friend of the Maldives."<ref>{{cite news|title = the Maldives condemns Bhutto's assassination|url = http://www.foreign.gov.mv/v3/?p=news&view=sep&nid=2444|date = 2007-12-28|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725032756/http://www.foreign.gov.mv/v3/?p=news&view=sep&nid=2444|archivedate = 2011-07-25|df = }}</ref> *{{NEP}} – [[List of Prime Ministers of Nepal|Prime Minister]] [[Girija Prasad Koirala]] said he was "shocked to hear the murder of Bhutto."<ref>{{cite news|title = Nepal condemns Bhutto's assassination|url = http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2007/dec/dec28/news13.php|accessdate = 2007-12-28}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *{{PHI}} – [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] condemned the assassination, saying "We mourn with the nation of Pakistan over the deaths of Benazir Bhutto and others killed in the shooting and bomb attack in Rawalpindi. news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7161590.stm|title=Benazir Bhutto killed in attack|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2007-12-27|date=2007-12-27}}</ref> In a statement addressed to Pervez name="RIA_Putin">{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20071227/94428422.html|title=Putin hopes those guilty of Bhutto's death will be punished|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27|publisher=RIA Novosti}}</ref> He also commented that "[f]orces of terrorism are challenging not only Pakistan, but the international community".<ref name="RIA_Putin" /> *{{ESP}} – [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]] [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]] said: "I want to express the most firm condemnation at the savage terrorist attack carried out in Rawalpindi."<ref name=telegraphquotes/> *{{SWE}} – [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Foreign Minister]] [[Carl Bildt]] said in a press conference about an hour after the murder that he felt both disgusted and angry for what had happened, and also worried over the further consequences.<ref>{{cite news|first=Thomas|last=Hall|author2=Svahn, Clas|title=Bildt: "Avsky och bestörtning"|url=http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=148&a=728294|publisher=DN.se|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515232831/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=148&a=728294|archivedate=2011-05-15|df=}}</ref> *{{CHE}} – The [[Foreign relations of Switzerland|Federal Department of Foreign Affairs]] released a statement strongly condemning the attack. It called on Pakistani authorities and all concerned actors to maintain the country's stability and to continue pursuing the democratic process.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.admin.ch/aktuell/00089/index.html?lang=en&msg-id=16500|title=Death of Mrs Benazir Bhutto|publisher=Admin.ch|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104013338/http://www.admin.ch/aktuell/00089/index.html?lang=en&msg-id=16500|archivedate=2008-01-04|df=}}</ref> *{{TUR}} – [[List of Prime Ministers of Turkey|Prime Minister]] [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] expressed his sorrow over Bhutto's demise during a phone conversation with Musharraf. Erdoğan, who strongly condemned the terrorist attack, also said that he hoped such attack would not hamper the democratization process in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstime7.com/haber/20071227/PM-Erdogan-condemns-assassination.php|title=PM Erdogan condemns assassination|publisher=newstime7.com|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[President of Turkey|President]] [[Abdullah Gül]], who met Bhutto during a visit to Pakistan earlier that month, called on the international community to assist Pakistan in this "critical" time as it prepares for parliamentary elections. Gül said: "They should own up to their country and make sure there is no more bloodshed".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnnturk.com/DUNYA/haber_detay.asp?PID=319&haberID=414940|language=Turkish|title=Benazir Butto suikasta kurban gitti|publisher=cnnturk.com|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> *{{UKR}} – [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada|Speaker of Parliament]] [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]], after the parliament had held a minute's silence, stated that [[Verkhovna Rada|Parliament]] "wished to extend its condolences to the family of the deceased (Bhutto), and to the Pakistani people for their loss."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/165093.html|title=Ukraine parliament holds minute silence at Bhutto killing|publisher=Earth Times|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> Ukraine's Foreign Ministry called for an objective and detailed investigation of the assassination of Pakistan's opposition leader Benazir Bhutto.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6329386.html|title=Ukraine urges detailed investigation into Bhutto's assassination}}</ref> *{{UK}} – [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]] stated, "Benazir Bhutto may have been killed by terrorists but the terrorists must not be allowed to kill democracy in Pakistan and this atrocity strengthens our resolve that terrorists will not win there, here or anywhere in the world."<ref name=BBCReaction/> Brown further stated those responsible were "cowards, afraid of democracy" and that the British government would "work with all in the Pakistani community in Britain and elsewhere in the world, so that we can have a peaceful, and safe, and democratic Pakistan."<ref name=BBCReaction /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/output/Page14097.asp|title=PM Pays Tribute to "Courageous" Bhutto|publisher=10 Downing Street|accessdate=2007-12-27|date=2007-12-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231035355/http://www.number10.gov.uk/output/Page14097.asp|archivedate=2007-12-31|df=}}</ref> [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[David Miliband]] released a statement saying, "In targeting Benazir Bhutto, extremist groups have in their sights all those committed to democratic processes in Pakistan. They cannot and must not succeed. This is a time for restraint but also unity," also stating that he was "deeply shocked."<ref name=death /><ref>{{cite news |first=Adrian|last=Croft|title=UK urges restraint after Bhutto killing |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L27197249.htm |publisher=AlertNet|work=Reuters |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[Secretary of State for Justice|Justice Secretary]] [[Jack Straw]] added in his statement, "The sense of grief at her senseless killing will I know be shared not just by Pakistani communities across the world but by everyone, because this terrorism is an attack on us all, regardless of race, religion or party. We will ensure that it is defeated."<ref>{{cite news |title=British PM Condemns Bhutto Killing |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/28/content_7326138.htm |publisher=Xinhua|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-29}}</ref>
== North America == *{{BAH}} – [[Heads of government of the Bahamas|Prime Minister]] [[Hubert Ingraham]] said, "Her assassination has left much of the world in a state of shock and grave concern for the future of Pakistan, the region and the world."<ref>{{cite news|title = Bahamas prime minister reacts to Bhutto's death |url =http://www.miamiherald.com/942/story/358881.html|accessdate = 2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{CAN}} – [[Canada Minister of Foreign Affairs|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Maxime Bernier]] issued the statement: "Canada condemns in the strongest terms this attack on the restoration of Pakistan's efforts to return to full democracy. Today's violence is especially heinous in view of the upcoming elections on January 8, 2008. The anti-democratic intent of the perpetrators could not be more obvious. I urge the Government and people of Pakistan to continue to reject all forms of violence and to resist those who seek to destabilize their country. Stability in Pakistan is vital for regional stability and security. We extend our deepest condolences to the family of Benazir Bhutto, to the families of the other victims of today's attack, and to the Pakistani people. Our thoughts are with them at this difficult time."<ref>{{cite news|title=Canada Condemns Assassination of Pakistani Opposition Leader Benazir Bhutto|publisher=Foreign Affairs and International Trade Canada|url=http://w01.international.gc.ca/minpub/Publication.aspx?isRedirect=True&publication_id=385720&language=E&docnumber=186|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103073906/http://w01.international.gc.ca/minpub/Publication.aspx?isRedirect=True&publication_id=385720&language=E&docnumber=186|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-01-03|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] later added to reporters at a press meeting in Calgary: "We condemn this attack in the strongest possible terms. This was an abhorrent act of terror. We hope that the government of Pakistan will act to bring the perpetrators to justice".<ref>{{cite news| title = Pakistani ex-prime minister Bhutto assassinated| publisher = CTV| url = http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20071227/pakistan_sharif_071227/20071227?hub=TopStories| date = 2007-12-27| accessdate = 2007-12-27| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071230094719/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20071227/pakistan_sharif_071227/20071227?hub=TopStories| archivedate = 2007-12-30| df = }}</ref> *{{JAM}} – [[Prime Minister of Jamaica|Prime Minister]] [[Bruce Golding]] expressed shock and outrage at the assassination and expressed the hope that "the Pakistani people will find lasting peace within a framework of democracy, tolerance and mutual respect."<ref>{{cite news|title = Prime Minister Expresses Shock at Assassination of Benazir Bhutto|url =http://www.jis.gov.jm/officePM/html/20071227T120000-0500_13873_JIS_PRIME_MINISTER_EXPRESSES_SHOCK_AT_ASSASSINATION_OF_BENAZIR_BHUTTO.asp |accessdate = 2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{MEX}} – [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Foreign Affairs Secretary]] [[Patricia Espinosa]] "energetically condemned" the event, reaffirmed Mexico's rejection of "terrorism in all its forms and the loss of innocent people's lives", and expressed their "deepest condolences to Benazir Bhutto's relatives and the families of the 20 other victims, as well as to the people and authorities of Pakistan."<ref name="Mexico's SRE">{{cite web|url=http://www.sre.gob.mx/csocial/contenido/comunicados/2007/dic/cp_375.html |title=Mexico condena el asesinato de la Ex Primer Ministro de Pakistán|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27|publisher=Mexican Foreign Affairs Secretariat|language=Spanish}}</ref> *{{TRI}} – The [[Politics of Trinidad and Tobago#Executive branch|Foreign Affairs Ministry]] released a statement, saying that "the Government and people of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago express the deepest sympathy to the Government and people of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan and family members of former Prime Minister Ms Benazir Ali Bhutto, political leader of the Pakistan People's Party, on the tragic incident which resulted in her untimely demise and that of innocent civilians", adding that "the Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago strongly condemns this act and reaffirms its unwavering commitment to international efforts to eradicate terrorism."<ref>{{cite news|title = Govt condemns killing|url =http://www.newsday.co.tt/news/0,70465.html |accessdate= 2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{USA}} – [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush|George Bush]] strongly condemned the assassination, urging her killers to be brought to justice.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bush condemns those killed Pakistan's Bhutto|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/WBT008135.htm|publisher=Reuters |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/12/20071227.html|title=President and Mrs. Bush Extend Condolences Regarding Assassination of Benazir Bhutto, Condemns Violence|publisher=The White House|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> Bush condemned the assassination as a "cowardly act by murderous extremists," and encouraged Pakistan to "honor Benazir Bhutto's memory by continuing with the democratic process for which she so bravely gave her life."<ref name="cnn" /><ref>{{cite news | title = Bush Condemns Bhutto Assassination | publisher = Reuters | date = 2007-12-27 | url = http://www.webcastr.com/videos/news/bush-condemns-assassination.html | accessdate = 2007-12-27 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071229150911/http://www.webcastr.com/videos/news/bush-condemns-assassination.html | archivedate = 2007-12-29 | df = }}</ref> Bush also offered some strong praise of Bhutto, noting that "she knew that her return to Pakistan earlier this year put her life at risk. Yet she refused to let assassins to dictate the course of her country."<ref>{{cite news|first=Steven Lee|last=Myers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/27/world/asia/28cnd-policy.html|title=Bush Condemns Assassination|publisher=The New York Times|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] said, "The brutal assassination of former Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is a tragic setback for the restoration of democracy in Pakistan. Her courageous return to Pakistan this year gave hope to all those concerned by efforts to extinguish rule of law there."<ref name=reactions>{{cite news |title=U.S. Reactions to Bhutto Assassination |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5ih0XVijOTzDEBsryLeXBsxkTkuDQD8TQ49TO1 |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231180258/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5ih0XVijOTzDEBsryLeXBsxkTkuDQD8TQ49TO1 |archive-date=2007-12-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Party Leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Majority Leader]] [[Harry Reid]] said, "It is important, when faced with the violence and loss of innocent life over the last few days, that political leaders show a commitment to resolve but also restraint. Extremists must be brought to justice, but extremism must not undermine commitment to the rule of law, to human rights, and to democracy."<ref name=reactions/> At another press briefing at around 13:00 [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] on December 27, a [[United States Department of State|State Department]] spokesman asserted that "some kind of postponement or delay" in Pakistan's democratic process would be "a victory" for "the extremists" who were responsible for Benazir Bhutto's assassination. He also asserted that "perhaps the best antidote to extremism is the continuation of the democratic process." He called for a "credible and transparent" investigation of the attack, and alluded to the "broad international outrage" about the incident.<ref>A press briefing with a [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] spokesman which was aired online as it occurred on {{cite news |title=CNN.com Live|url=http://www.cnn.com/video/live/live.html?stream=stream1|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> He also said that Bush spoke with Musharraf at 13:15 [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Tabassum |last=Zakaria |title=Bush has spoken with Musharraf: White House |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/articles/2007/12/27/bush_has_spoken_with_musharraf_white_house/ |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations|Ambassador to the United Nations]] [[Zalmay Khalilzad]], while describing Bhutto as a “courageous figure”, said that “The world has much at stake in the success of Pakistan's democratic institutions. It's a great tragedy because she stood for moderation, for rule of law, for democracy in her country, and her death is a loss for the cause of moderation, democracy, and rule of law for Pakistan. She was clear-headed about the problems of her country, the challenges that she faced — even the security challenges she faced."<ref>{{cite news |title=UN condemns Bhutto assassination as a "reprehensible act" |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/12/27/news/UN-GEN-UN-Pakistan.php|date=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Condoleezza Rice]] said in a statement,"We extend our sincere condolences to the Bhutto family and to the families of others who were killed and wounded in the attack. We condemn in the strongest terms possible this cowardly and murderous attack."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2007/12/98063.htm |title=Assassination of Benazir Bhutto: Statement by Secretary Condoleezza Rice |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2008-01-03 |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101102815/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2007/12/98063.htm |archivedate=2008-01-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Oceania == *{{AUS}} – [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Kevin Rudd]] urged restraint, saying "Benazir Bhutto showed great courage and defiance in her resistance to extremism. I urge all parties in Pakistan to act with restraint and to work for a return to a peaceful democratic process. It is my hope that a democratic Pakistan will be Benazir Bhutto's legacy."<ref>{{cite news|title=Rudd condemns killing|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/rudd-condemns-killing/2007/12/28/1198778656134.html|publisher= [[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> *{{FIJ}} – [[Cabinet of Fiji|Finance Minister]] [[Mahendra Chaudhry]] said, "Ms. Bhutto was, in recent times, a beacon of hope for the millions of Pakistani people who aspired for a free, fair and democratic Pakistan. It is a real tragedy that Ms Bhutto has not been allowed to realise her vision for Pakistan and the rest of the world."<ref>{{cite news|title = FLP saddened by death of Bhutto|publisher = [[Fiji Times]]|url = http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=77481|date = 2007-12-28|accessdate = 2007-12-28|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080103092831/http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=77481|archive-date = 2008-01-03|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref> *{{NZL}} – [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Prime Minister]] [[Helen Clark]] said she was deeply shocked and saddened saying "Benazir Bhutto showed great courage in returning to Pakistan to contest the election. She had survived attempts on her life and was acutely aware of the dangers she faced in returning to campaign for the elections. Her death is a great loss to Pakistan and to the region. My sympathies go out to her immediate family, political colleagues, and to the people of Pakistan for their terrible loss."<ref>{{cite news|title=New Zealand leader praises Bhutto's courage|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/topic/story.cfm?c_id=124&objectid=10484496|publisher= [[New Zealand Herald]]|date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref>
== South America == *{{ARG}} – [[President of Argentina|President]] [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] condemned "energetically the awful attack that (...) took the life of Benazir Bhutto. The Argentine government wishes to express its deepest condolences to the Bhutto family, as well to the other victims' families and the whole people of Pakistan".<ref>{{cite news |title=Enérgico repudio del Gobierno|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/exterior/nota.asp?nota_id=974336&pid=3723753&toi=5262|publisher=La Nación|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> *{{BOL}} – The Ministry of Foreign Affairs sent a letter to [[UN]] asking for an investigation of the assassination. In name of [[President of Bolivia|President]] [[Evo Morales]] it expressed Bolivia's condemnation of the attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espanol.upi.com/Politica/2007/12/28/Bolivia-pide-a-la-ONU-esclarecer-asesinato-de-Benazir-Bhutto/UPI-29661198879560/|title=Bolivia pide a la ONU esclarecer asesinato de Benazir Bhutto|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2011-10-14|publisher=[[UPI]]|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331150102/http://espanol.upi.com/Politica/2007/12/28/Bolivia-pide-a-la-ONU-esclarecer-asesinato-de-Benazir-Bhutto/UPI-29661198879560/|archivedate=2012-03-31|df=}}</ref> *{{BRA}} – [[President of Brazil|President]] [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] condemned the attacks and spoke of his "great pain and indignation" at the violence.<ref>{{cite news|title=World Leaders Shocked |url=http://www.nation.com.pk/daily/dec-2007/28/index3.php |publisher=The Nation |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231063147/http://www.nation.com.pk/daily/dec-2007/28/index3.php |archivedate=2007-12-31 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Later, in a statement, Lula da Silva reaffirmed his "firm rejection to the use of violence in political life" and extended his condolences "to the families of the victims and the Pakistani nation" in the name of the [[Politics of Brazil|Brazilian Government]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/mundo/ult94u358474.shtml|title=Veja a repercussão internacional sobre a morte de Bhutto|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-28|publisher=[[Folha de S. Paulo]]|language=Portuguese}}</ref> *{{CHI}} – [[President of Chile|President]] [[Michelle Bachelet]] condemned the assassination<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/28/content_7328885.htm|title=Latin America condemns murder of Bhutto|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2011-10-14|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108062634/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/28/content_7328885.htm|archivedate=2008-01-08|df=}}</ref> and paid tribute to Bhutto.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2004095778_pakistanreax28.html|title=World leaders condemn attack, laud Bhutto|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2011-10-14|publisher=[[The Seattle Times]]|first=Andrew O.|last=Selsky}}</ref> The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Chile)|Foreign Affairs Ministry]] expressed deep consternation at the loss of Bhutto and condemned the events as "terrorist acts." The ministry also expressed its hope that "this event does not dim the opening process towards a total democracy and the national reconciliation."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minrel.gob.cl/prontus_minrel/site/artic/20080716/pags/20080716185041.php |title=Chile expresa profunda consternación por la muerte de Benazir Bhutto |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2011-10-14 |publisher=Chilean Ministry of Foreign Affairs |language=Spanish |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080313030322/http://www.minrel.gov.cl/webMinRel/showNoti.do?noticia=4699&&agina=bajada-noticia-sb.jsp |archivedate=2008-03-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{GUY}} – The Foreign Affairs Ministry sent an official message conveying the condolences of the government and people of Guyana and hoped "peace and stability will prevail."<ref>{{cite news|title=Guyana regrets Bhutto death |url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/index.pl/article_general_news?id=56535824 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20080102113719/http://www.stabroeknews.com/index.pl/article_general_news?id=56535824 |archivedate=2008-01-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{PAR}} – The [[Foreign relations of Paraguay|Foreign Affairs Ministry]] issued a statement expressing its rejection of "acts of violence and the loss of human life", repudiating "acts of terrorism in any of its manifestations", and "[sending] to the Bhutto family, to the families of other victims, as well as to the people and authorities of Pakistan, its sincere condolences."<ref>{{cite news|title = Paraguay condemned the "barbaric" attack |url =http://es.noticias.yahoo.com/efe/20071227/twl-paraguay-condena-el-barbaro-atentado-e1e34ad_1.html|accessdate = 2007-12-28|language=Spanish}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> *{{PER}} – [[List of Presidents of Peru|President]] [[Alan García]] stated at the [[Government Palace (Peru)|Casa de Pizarro]] that "[[Peru]] reaffirms its absolute opposition to terrorism, which must firmly be fought with total respect to human rights and democratic liberties." Garcia expressed the condolences of the [[Peru]]vian people to Bhutto's family and hoped that [[Pakistan]] would soon find order.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rpp.com.pe/portada/politica/108980_1.php|title=Alan García condena el asesinato de Benazir Bhutto|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229002314/http://www.rpp.com.pe/portada/politica/108980_1.php|archivedate=2007-12-29|df=}}</ref> It was also revealed that García was a close friend of Bhutto, according to a [[Foreign relations of Peru|Chancellorship]] note. *{{VEN}} – [[List of Presidents of Venezuela|President]] [[Hugo Chávez]] said, "We received the news with great pain, and I hope this is never repeated ever again, anywhere."<ref>{{cite news |title=World leaders laud Bhutto, fear for Pakistan |url= http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/news/world/world-leaders-laud-bhutto-fear-for-pakistan/2007/12/28/1198778695152.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2 |date=2007-12-28}}</ref>
== International organisations== *{{flag|Arab League}} – [[Arab League#Secretaries General|Secretary General]] [[Amr Moussa]] strongly condemned the assassination, saying: "We condemn this assassination and terrorist act, and pray for God Almighty to bless her soul."<ref>{{cite news |title= Arab League condemns Bhutto''s assassination|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/newsagenciespublicsite/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=1870944&Language=en |publisher=Kuwait News Agency (KUNA)|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> * [[Commonwealth of Nations]] – [[Commonwealth Secretary-General|Secretary-General]] [[Don McKinnon]] said "I hope that this terrible tragedy will make crystal clear the folly of violence and the importance of restraint and reconciliation as the only way of consolidating the democratic process. The Commonwealth stands by Pakistan in that effort.”<ref>{{cite web |title= Commonwealth Secretary-General condemns assassination of Benazir Bhutto |url= http://www.thecommonwealth.org/news/173944/271207bhutto.htm |date= 2007-12-27 |accessdate= 2007-12-30 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071231092926/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/news/173944/271207bhutto.htm |archivedate= 2007-12-31 |df= }}</ref> *{{EU}} – [[President of the European Commission|European Commission President]] [[José Manuel Barroso]] condemned the assassination as "an attack against democracy and against Pakistan," and "[hopes] that Pakistan will remain firmly on track for return to democratic civilian rule."<ref name=BBCReaction /> [[Vice-President of the European Commission|First Vice President]] [[Margot Wallström]] said, "In a region of such global importance, Benazir's was a rare woman's voice speaking out for democracy and against violence. Much of her life was spent working for these values. I am saddened by this loss and send condolences to her family and to the people of Pakistan. I hope that democracy will prevail there and that the country will remain on track for a return to democratic civilian rule."<ref name="CWWL">{{cite web|url=http://www.cwwl.org/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030810040704/http://www.cwwl.org/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2003-08-10|title=Council of Women World Leaders|date=2007-12-27|accessdate=2007-12-29}}</ref> *{{flag|Organisation of the Islamic Conference}} – [[Organisation of the Islamic Conference#Permanent Secretariat|Secretary General]] [[Ekmeleddin İhsanoğlu]] "condemned in strongest terms the outrageous and brutal murder of the former Prime Minister of Pakistan and leader of Pakistan People's Party, Ms. Benazir Bhutto in a shocking suicide attack in [[Rawalpindi]]."<ref>{{cite news |title=OIC Secretary General condemns killing of Benazir Bhutto |url=http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=24567&Itemid=2 |publisher=Associated Press(APP) |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230195800/http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=24567&Itemid=2 |archivedate=2007-12-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{UNO}} – [[United Nations Secretary-General|Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] said: "I strongly condemn this heinous crime and call for the perpetrators to be brought to justice as soon as possible. This represents an assault on stability in Pakistan and its democratic processes."<ref>{{cite news |title=Secretary-General 'shocked and outraged' by Bhutto assassination|url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs//2007/sgsm11352.doc.htm |publisher=UN Department of Public Information |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> The [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] held an emergency meeting and unanimously condemned the assassination.<ref>{{cite news |title=Security Council, in presidential statement, condemns 'in strongest terms' suicide attack that killed former prime minister of Pakistan |url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs//2007/sc9217.doc.htm |publisher=UN Department of Public Information |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-28}}</ref> * [[World Bank Group]] – [[World Bank Group#Presidency|President]] [[Robert Zoellick]] said, "This tragedy will only hinder Pakistan's critical agenda of meeting the urgent needs of its many citizens. On behalf of the World Bank Group, I would like to extend my sympathies and deepest condolences to Ms. Bhutto's family and to the families of the other victims of this tragic event."<ref>{{cite news |first=Wang |last=Hongjiang |title= World Bank chief says shocked by death of Bhutto |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/28/content_7328445.htm |publisher=Zinhuanet|date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref>
== Non-governmental organisations == * {{flagicon image|Flag of Jihad.svg}} [[Al-Qaeda]] – Spokesman [[Mustafa Abu al-Yazid]] was quoted by the Philippine media as saying that "we terminated the most precious American {{Sic}} asset who vowed to defeat the [[mujahideen]]."<ref>{{cite news |title=Pakistan: Al-Qaeda Claims Bhutto Assassination |url=http://www.pacificnewscenter.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=1&twindow=Default&mad=No&sdetail=17952&wpage=&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1718&hn=pacificnewscenter&he=.com |publisher=Pacific News Center |date=2007-12-28 |accessdate=2007-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102082514/http://www.pacificnewscenter.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=1&twindow=Default&mad=No&sdetail=17952&wpage=&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1718&hn=pacificnewscenter&he=.com |archivedate=2008-01-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
* {{flagicon|Afghanistan|Taliban}} However, a spokesman for Al-Qaeda-linked [[Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan]] leader [[Baitullah Mehsud]] was quoted the following day as saying: "I strongly deny it. [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas|Tribal people]] have their own customs. We don't strike women."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/12/29/2128806.htm|title=Al Qaeda militant did not kill Bhutto: spokesman|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=2007-12-29|accessdate=2007-12-31}}</ref> *[[Amnesty International]] – [[Asia]]n Program Director Catherine Baber said: "It is shocking to see someone's life cut short in such a brutal way. Attacks such as these can never be justified. They violate international law and the rules of democratic behavior. We know that the government of President Musharraf will find itself under enormous pressure to go after the culprits and keep the country calm and stable, but Amnesty International calls on President Musharraf – and on the security forces – to exercise restraint and uphold the rule of law. The killing of Benazir Bhutto must not be allowed to become a setback to civilian governance or indeed lead to a further crackdown on civil liberties."<ref>{{cite news |title=Amnesty International Condemns Assassination of Benazir Bhutto |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/amnesty-international-condemns-assassination-benazir-bhutto-20071227|date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27}}</ref> [[Amnesty International USA|AI United States Government Relations Director]] Alex Arriaga said: "Pakistan is at a dangerous crossroads. If it cannot rely on an [[independent judiciary]], some of the most dangerous aspects of [[martial law]] will become enshrined in its legal and political system, leaving the people's human rights in the balance. The United States government must press its ally, which has used the '[[War on Terrorism|War on Terror]]' to justify its actions, and put an end to this slippery slope. Without these steps, the Bush administration will further acquiesce that fundamental rights can be denied, and those who oppose Musharraf are likely to face intimidation – or even death."<ref>{{cite news |title=Amnesty to Musharraf: No excuse for a crackdown |url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/news/politics/blog/2007/12/amnesty_to_musharraf_no_excuse.html |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2007-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231133051/http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/news/politics/blog/2007/12/amnesty_to_musharraf_no_excuse.html |archivedate=2007-12-31 |df= }}</ref> *[[Human Rights Watch]] – A statement was calling the assassination a "tragic event with serious implications for Pakistan's transition to democracy" and stating that "political violence of this nature has claimed far too many innocent lives in Pakistan and it must stop. Benazir Bhutto was a democrat who believed in the supremacy of constitutional rule and throughout her career, sought power through the ballot box. Today, she died campaigning for votes and calling for a free election." HRW South Asia researcher, speaking for the organization, called on the Pakistani government to "undertake an independent and transparent investigation into Bhutto's assassination and fully cooperate with such an investigation."<ref>[http://hrw.org/english/docs/2007/12/27/pakist17661.htm Pakistan: Bhutto Assassination a Tragedy: Crucial to Uphold Fundamental Rights to Prevent Turmoil]. Human Rights Watch 27 Dec. 2007.</ref>

Lucamar Productions
Marc Platt Productions | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2014|12|08|[[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]]|2014|12|25|United States}} | runtime = 124 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/woods-film | title=''INTO THE WOODS'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 11, 2014 | accessdate=November 11, 2014}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $50 million | gross = $213.1 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=intothewoods.htm |title=Into the Woods | website=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=November 28, 2015}} }} '''''Into the Woods''''' is a 2014 American [[Musical film|musical]] [[fantasy film]] directed by [[Rob Marshall]], and [[Film adaptation|adapted to the screen]] by [[James Lapine]] from his and [[Stephen Sondheim]]'s [[Into the Woods|1986 Broadway musical of the same name]].{{cite news|last=Ng|first=David|title=Sam Mendes, Rob Marshall will revive their revival of 'Cabaret{{'-}} |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-sam-mendes-rob-marshall-cabaret-20130905,0,7675194.story |accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 5, 2013}} A [[Walt Disney Pictures]] production, it features an [[ensemble cast]] that includes [[Meryl Streep]], [[Emily Blunt]], [[James Corden]], [[Anna Kendrick]], [[Chris Pine]], [[Tracey Ullman]], [[Christine Baranski]], [[Lilla Crawford]], [[Daniel Huttlestone]], [[MacKenzie Mauzy]], [[Billy Magnussen]], and [[Johnny Depp]]. Inspired by the [[Brothers Grimm|Grimm Brothers]]' fairy tales of "[[Little Red Riding Hood]]", "[[Cinderella]]", "[[Jack and the Beanstalk]]", and "[[Rapunzel]]", the film is a [[fantasy genre]] centered on a childless couple, who set out to end a curse placed on them by a vengeful witch. Ultimately, the characters are forced to rectify the consequences of their actions.{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|author2=Tatiana Siegel|title=Chris Pine, Jake Gyllenhaal Circling Musical 'Into the Woods' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/chris-pine-jake-gyllenhaal-circling-522404|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=May 14, 2013}} After several unsuccessful attempts by other studios and producers to adapt the musical to film, Disney announced in 2012 that it was producing an adaptation, with Marshall directing and John DeLuca serving as producer. [[Principal photography]] commenced in September 2013, and took place entirely in the [[United Kingdom]], including at [[Shepperton Studios]] in [[London]]. ''Into the Woods'' held its [[Premiere|world premiere]] at the [[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]] in [[New York City]] on December 8, 2014, and was released theatrically in the United States on December 25, 2014.{{cite news|last=Schillaci|first=Sophie|title=Disney Dates Musical 'Into the Woods' Opposite 'Annie' in December 2014|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-dates-musical-woods-opposite-568528|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 13, 2013|author2=Pamela McClintock}} The film was commercially successful and received generally positive reviews, receiving praise for its acting performances, visual style, and production merits, but received criticism for its lighter tone compared to the source material and the changes made for the film translation. It grossed $213 million worldwide.{{cite news|last1=Piccalo|first1=Gina|title=Record-breaking 'Into the Woods' is a surprise hit|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-into-the-woods-20150106-story.html|accessdate=January 9, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=January 5, 2015}} ''Into the Woods'' received three [[Academy Award]] nominations at the [[87th Academy Awards]], including a [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] nomination for Streep, and three [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations at the [[72nd Golden Globe Awards]], including [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]]. ==Plot== A baker ([[James Corden]]) and his wife ([[Emily Blunt]]) wish for a child but suffer under a curse laid upon the baker's family by a [[Witchcraft|Witch]] ([[Meryl Streep]]) who found the baker's father robbing her garden when his mother was pregnant. Because the baker's father also stole some magic beans, the witch's own mother cursed her to be ugly. The witch is able to lift the curse and allow them to have a child, but only if the baker and his wife obtain four critical items for her to make a potion: a white cow, a red cape, a yellow strand of hair, and a golden slipper, none of which she is allowed to touch. The witch's demands eventually bring the baker and his wife into contact with Jack ([[Daniel Huttlestone]]), who is selling his beloved cow, Milky-White, and to whom the baker offers magic beans left him by his father (which were stolen from the witch) which grow into a large beanstalk; with Red Riding Hood ([[Lilla Crawford]]), whose red cape the couple noticed when she stopped by the bakery earlier to buy bread and sweets on her way to grandmother's house; with blonde-haired Rapunzel ([[MacKenzie Mauzy]]), whose tower the baker's wife passes in the woods; and with Cinderella ([[Anna Kendrick]]), who also runs into the baker's wife while fleeing from the pursuing prince ([[Chris Pine]]) and whose ball outfit includes gold slippers. After a series of failed attempts and misadventures, the baker and his wife are finally able to gather the items necessary to break the spell. Meanwhile, each of the other characters receives a "[[happy ending]]": Cinderella marries the prince; Rapunzel is freed from her guardian, the witch, by Cinderella's prince's brother and marries him; Jack provides for his mother by stealing riches from the [[Giant]] in the sky, and kills the pursuing giant by cutting down the beanstalk; Little Red Riding Hood and her grandmother are saved from the [[Big Bad Wolf]] ([[Johnny Depp]]); and the witch regains her youth and beauty after drinking the potion. However, each of the characters learns that their endings don't remain happy: the baker is worried that he is a poor father to his newborn baby; the baker's wife is temporarily seduced by the prince; Cinderella is disenchanted by her cheating prince; and the witch learns that she has lost her magic powers. The growth of a second beanstalk from the last remaining magic bean allows the giant's wife to climb down and threaten the kingdom and its inhabitants if they do not deliver Jack in retribution for killing her husband. The characters attempt to find Jack, but debate the morality of handing Jack over. In the process, Red Riding Hood's mother and grandmother, Jack's mother, and the baker's wife are killed. The characters blame each other for their individual actions that led to the tragedy, ultimately blaming the witch for growing the beans in the first place. She curses them for their inability to accept responsibility for their individual actions. Casting all the remaining beans away, the witch begs her mother to punish her again, hoping to regain her powers, but instead she disappears into a large pit of boiling tar. The remaining characters resolve to kill the threatening giant's wife though Cinderella and the baker try to explain to the distraught Red Riding Hood and Jack the complicated morality of retribution and revenge. The characters lure the giant's wife into stepping in the tar pit where she ultimately trips and falls to her death. With the giant's wife dead, the characters move forward with their ruined lives. The baker, thinking of his wife, is determined to be a good father. Cinderella decides to leave the prince and help the baker, and Jack and Red Riding Hood, now orphans, are living with the baker and Cinderella. The baker comforts his son after he begins to cry by telling the story of the film as the movie ends with the witch's moral, meaning that children can change due to the parent's actions and behaviors.
