{{Cite check|date=October 2012}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Violence against women}} The '''Shafia Family murders''' took place on June 30, 2009 in [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]], Ontario. Shafia sisters Zainab, 19, Sahar, 17, and Geeti, 13, along with Rona Amir Mohammed, 50, (all Afghan origin) were found dead inside a car that was discovered underwater in front of the northernmost [[Kingston Mills]] [[canal lock|lock]] of the [[Rideau Canal]] on the same day.<ref name="TWS">{{cite web | title = A timeline of the Kingston canal deaths | publisher = [[Windsor Star]] | url = https://windsorstar.com/news/timeline+Kingston+canal+deaths/1824608/story.html | date = July 24, 2009 | accessdate =July 25, 2009}}</ref> Zainab, Sahar, and Geeti were daughters of Mohammad Shafia, 58 and his wife Tooba Mohammad Yahya, 41. The couple also had a son Hamed, 20, and three other children. Rona, who was herself infertile, was the first wife of Mohammad Shafia in their [[polygamy|polygamous]] household.
On July 23, 2009, Mohammad, Tooba Yahya, and Hamed were arrested on charges of four counts of [[First degree murder#First and second degree|first degree murder]] and conspiracy to commit murder under the guise of [[honour killing]].<ref name="CBC">{{cite news | title = Shafia daughter married for revenge, court hears | publisher = [[CBC News]] | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2011/11/10/shafia-trial-nov10.html | date = November 10, 2011 | accessdate =November 10, 2011}}</ref><ref name="TTS">{{cite news | title = Shining a light on honour killings' dark corner |work=Toronto Star | url = https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/671779 | date = July 25, 2009 | accessdate =July 25, 2009 | first=Daniel | last=Dale}}</ref> They were found guilty of all four counts by the jury in January 2012. The trial, which took place at the [[Frontenac County Court House]], was believed to be the first in Canada conducted in four languages – English, French, [[Dari language|Dari]] and Spanish.<ref>[http://www.thewhig.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?archive=true&e=3327207 Jury selection for murder trial begins next week] from [[The Kingston Whig-Standard]]. Retrieved November 24, 2011.</ref>
The trial garnered media attention in Canada for several months, and raised the debate over Canadian values, [[honour crimes]], and violence among Muslim groups.
==Background== In 1979 or 1980, Mohammad Shafia married Rona Mohammed. The couple did not have children, and medical tests confirmed that Rona was unable to have children. In keeping with Afghan custom, and at Rona's behest, Mohammad Shafia took Tooba Yahya as his second wife. The second wedding took place in 1989, and Rona features prominently in many wedding photographs, many of which feature Shafia flanked by his two wives. The three of them lived together in one household, as is customary, and Tooba gave birth to seven children. Rona participated fully in raising and caring for the children and bonded strongly with them, as though they were her own. Her relationship with her co-wife was, however, less idyllic.
The Shafia family left [[Afghanistan]] in 1992. They moved to Australia for a brief while, and then to the [[United Arab Emirates]], where they lived for over a decade. Mohammad Shafia made a considerable fortune in [[Dubai]], working in the used car business and later diversifying into real estate.<ref name="macleans1">{{cite web|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/tag/shafia-trial/ |title=shafia trial – Topics |publisher=Macleans.ca |accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref> By 2007, he was a millionaire many times over, and decided to take advantage of an immigration programme introduced by the government of [[Quebec]] in [[Canada]], which offered permanent residence and eventual citizenship to people who invested significant money in the province. Shafia invested $2 million in purchasing a strip-mall on the outskirts of [[Montreal]], and a further $200,000 in building a spacious new house for his family. Shafia, his second wife Tooba and their seven children immigrated to Canada and settled in the [[St. Leonard, Quebec|Saint-Léonard]] [[Boroughs of Montreal|borough]] of [[Montreal]] in 2007.<ref name="TNP">{{cite web|title=Picture of troubled family emerges |work=National Post |location=Canada |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/story.html?id=1826842&p=2 |date=July 25, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="chronology"/> Five months later, Shafia sponsored the immigration of Rona, telling the authorities that she was his cousin and that she would work as a cook and housekeeper.<ref name="montrealgazette1">{{cite web|last=Tripp |first=Rob |url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/canada-in-afghanistan/Shafia+trial+told+abuse+violence+against+woman/5784534/story.html |title=Shafia trial told of abuse, violence against woman |publisher=Montrealgazette.com |date=November 30, 2011 |accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref><ref>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2012/01/09/dimanno_accused_mother_testifies_at_shafia_murder_trial.html</ref><ref>https://montrealgazette.com/news/Accused+says+heart+often+bleeds+cries+only+once+stand/5970215/story.html?id=5970215{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
According to a family member's interview, Rona was trapped in an abusive, loveless marriage, trying in vain to convince her husband to grant her a divorce. Rona's siblings claimed that she feared for her life during the days leading up to her death.<ref name="CBC1">{{cite news|title=Oldest canal victim feared for her life: siblings |publisher=[[CBC News]] |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/07/24/montreal-canal-deaths-rona-mohammed-siblings.html?ref=rss |date=July 24, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090727132811/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/07/24/montreal-canal-deaths-rona-mohammed-siblings.html?ref=rss |archivedate=July 27, 2009 }}</ref> Tooba, the second wife, allegedly said to Rona “You are a slave, you are a servant.” Reportedly, the Shafias held all of Rona’s identity documents, including her passport, so Rona believed she could not flee to another country, where she had relatives. <ref name="montrealgazette1"/> It was reported that Rona came to Canada as a domestic servant on a visitor's visa and the "[visa's] renewal held over her head like an axe ready to fall" by her husband and co-wife. <ref>{{cite web |author=CHRISTIE BLATCHFORD, The Gazette January 30, 2012 |url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/There+honour+shameless+murders/6070834/story.html#ixzz1kxIMoovV |title=Christie Blatchford: There's no honour in 'shameless murders' |publisher=Montrealgazette.com |accessdate=January 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131072636/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/There+honour+shameless+murders/6070834/story.html#ixzz1kxIMoovV |archivedate=January 31, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
They also stated that the family's eldest daughter Zainab's relationship with a [[Pakistani people|Pakistani]] boy was a source of much anger for her father, and they claimed to have overheard the father's threats to kill her.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Allison|title=Shafia sisters complained about violence at home months before their deaths|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/home-life-improving-woman-allegedly-killed-family-court-160133520.html|publisher=The Canadian Press via Yahoo news|date=November 22, 2011|accessdate=February 1, 2012}}</ref>
With parents Mohammad Shafia and Tooba Mohammad Yahya, and eldest son Hamed Shafia all in custody during the trial, the remaining Shafia children (two girls and a boy) were being cared for under social services.<ref name="macleans1"/>
==Investigation== On June 30, 2009, a black [[Nissan Sentra]] with a broken left [[taillight]] was spotted submerged at the [[Kingston Mills]] locks, with four female bodies found inside. Mohammad Shafia was at the [[Kingston Police]] station to report that four of their family – three teenage daughters and a purported aunt – were missing.<ref name=chronology>{{cite web|title=Chronology of events in the Shafia murders|accessdate=January 30, 2012|url=http://montreal.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20120129/shafia-trial-choronology-120129/20120129/?hub=MontrealHome|date=January 29, 2012}}</ref> Police initially believed that it was a tragic, if bizarre, accident, and first categorized it as a "sudden death investigation".
However, authorities soon learned that Hamed had reported an accident with the family [[Lexus]] SUV in an empty parking lot early that same morning in [[Montreal]]. Despite their suspicions, the authorities did not have "reasonable and probable grounds" or sufficient evidence to ask a judge for a [[search warrant]]. Kingston Police Det. Steve Koopman, the liaison with the Shafia family, managed to gain the Shafias' [[consent]] so that they could view the Lexus. After assessing the damage on both vehicles, police theorized that the Lexus was used to ram the Nissan into the locks.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://vancouversun.com/business/fp/yourmoney/Blatchford+Meet+Nice+detective+Shafia+trust/5769418/story.html |title=Blatchford: Meet Mr. Nice Cop – the detective who won the Shafia clan's trust |work=Vancouver Sun |date=November 25, 2011 |accessdate=January 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231110850/http://www.vancouversun.com/business/fp/yourmoney/Blatchford+Meet+Nice+detective+Shafia+trust/5769418/story.html |archivedate=December 31, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
It has been reported that the Shafia family purchased the used Nissan Sentra for [[Canadian dollar|CAD]]$5,000 one day before the family left Montreal for Niagara Falls.<ref>{{cite web|author=CHRISTIE BLATCHFORD, National Post January 29, 2012 |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/full-comment/jury-reaches-verdict-in-shafia-trial |title=Christie Blatchford: No honour in 'cold-blooded, shameless' murder of Shafia girls |publisher=nationalpost.com |accessdate=April 13, 2017}}</ref>
==Trial== [[Jury selection]] began on October 11, and the trial officially began on October 20.<ref name=chr>{{cite news|last=Rocha|first=Roberto|title=Road to a guilty verdict|url=https://calgaryherald.com/news/Road+guilty+verdict/6076269/story.html|accessdate=January 31, 2012|newspaper=Calgary Herald|date=January 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128185142/http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Road+guilty+verdict/6076269/story.html|archivedate=January 28, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The trial was presided over by [[Ontario Superior Court]] Judge Robert Maranger.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/01/29/shafia-reaction.html|title=Key players in Shafia trial react to verdict |date= January 29, 2012 |publisher=CBC |location= Canada }}</ref>
===Verdict=== On January 29, 2012, the jury completed its deliberation after 15 hours and reached a verdict of guilty, four counts of first degree murder for each of the three defendants. First degree murder carries an automatic sentence of life in prison without a possibility of parole for 25 years.<ref name="verdict">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/01/29/shafia-sunday.html |title=Shafia jury finds all guilty |date=January 29, 2012 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=January 29, 2012}}</ref>
==Media coverage of the Shafia murder trial==
The coverage of the Shafia murder trial was widespread, often being on the front page of newspapers and the top story in TV newscasts. Since the case involved Afghan Canadians, questions arose as to whether or not it was correct, or even appropriate, to call the murders [[honour killing]] or simply [[domestic violence]]. While the judge who deliberated on the case referred to the act simply as murder, the media chose a different course when it called the murder "honour killing". Across media outlets, the murder was framed as such. A [[publication ban]] placed on the case prevented the media from naming the three children that are still alive, with Hamed being the fourth.
===CBC===
[[CBC News]] covered the trials from day 1 and went a step further by publishing its audience's comments to show how Canadians feel about the case and its details. The CBC stated that the story garnered many comments from the viewers but that they decided to publish a select few. Furthermore, the CBC did a "summary" of the comments and said that people generally "agreed with the verdict, applauding the court and the jury for its decision after the three-month trial."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/yourcommunity/2012/01/community-reaction-to-the-shafia-trial-verdict.html |title=Community reaction to the Shafia trial verdict |date=January 30, 2012 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=April 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404231106/http://www.cbc.ca/news/yourcommunity/2012/01/community-reaction-to-the-shafia-trial-verdict.html |archivedate=April 4, 2012 }}</ref>
===CTV===
[[CTV News]] published a piece saying that the trial has cast a shadow over Canada's Islamic community, further tarnishing an image that has not yet recovered from the events of 9/11. But like other media outlets, CTV has asked the Muslim community to clarify their stance on the issue of honour killing. “Muslims across the country, however, say the revelations in a Kingston, Ont., courtroom have shone a light on problematic aspects of their culture and illuminated new ways to tackle the issues.”<ref name="Media Coverage of the Trials">{{cite news |url=http://ottawa.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20120130/mtl_shafia_community_120130/20120130/|title=Shafia murder trial casts shadow over Canada's Islamic community |date=January 30, 2012 |publisher=CTV News |accessdate=April 5, 2012}}</ref>
CTV also published a timeline of not just the events that took place in Canada but also going back all the way to the Shafia family’s days in Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120129/shafia-trial-choronology-120129/#ixzz1rD50C0Tn |title=Chronology of events in the Shafia murders |date=January 29, 2012 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=April 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402112159/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120129/shafia-trial-choronology-120129#ixzz1rD50C0Tn |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===''Ottawa Citizen''===
Pascale Fournier, writing for ''[[The Ottawa Citizen]]'', said that there was a greater tragedy in the failure of the state to intervene before the murders occurred, and that vulnerable groups from immigrant communities need the most protection but rarely get it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fournier|first=Pascale|title=Media coverage of Shafia case sometimes fuelled prejudices|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/Shafia+trial+only+beginning/6075736/story.html|publisher=Guelph Mercury|accessdate=April 5, 2012|date=January 31, 2012}}{{Dead link|date=October 2012}}</ref>
===''The Globe and Mail''===
In addition to covering every detail of the trial, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' published a piece with the "ten most shocking quotes" from the Shafia trial one of which was by Crown attorney Gerard Laarhuis after the verdicts which is as follows:
“This jury found that four strong, vivacious and freedom-loving women were murdered by their own family in the most troubling of circumstances. We all think of these four, wonderful women now who died needless deaths. This verdict sends a very clear message about our Canadian values and the core principles in a free and democratic society that all Canadians enjoy and even visitors to Canada enjoy.”<ref name="Media Coverage of the Trials"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/01/29/shafia-sunday.html |title=Shafia jury finds all guilty |date=January 29, 2012 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=April 5, 2012}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Only part of this quotation is given by these sources. |date=October 2012}}
This was one of the most criticized quotes by Afghan Canadians, as they asserted that intolerance towards violence against women is not just a Canadian value but a universal value and Afghans like any other peoples condemn the acts of the perpetrators.
===''Montreal Gazette''===
The ''[[Montreal Gazette]]'' published a column in which it said that labelling the murders as honour killing is a mistake because domestic violence against women is ubiquitous and framing it into a particular category would mean distancing oneself from a crime that is all too common. The authors argue that premeditation is put forth as a core component to differentiate honour killings from other types of murders, such as crimes of convenience or crimes of passion. However, recent studies indicate that premeditation is as much a component in other cases of domestic violence and murder as it is in "honour killings."
"Calling the murders "honour killings" accomplishes two goals. First, it makes it seem as if femicide is a highly unusual event. Second, it makes it seem as if femicide is confined to specific populations within Canada and specific national cultures or religions in the world at large. But Canadian statistics prove otherwise. According to StatsCan figures, from 2000 to 2009 an average of 58 women a year were killed in this country as a result of spousal violence. In that same period, 67 children and young people aged 12 to 17 were murdered by family members. In contrast, recent estimates tell us that there have been 12 or 13 so-called honour killings in Canada in the last decade. It does not take a genius to see that comparing 12 or 13 against the hundreds of women and children who were victims of familial violence serves only to frame "honour killing" as peculiar, when in reality it is part of a larger pattern of violence against women."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/Should+call+honour+killing/6075589/story.html |title=Should we call it 'honour killing'? |date=January 31, 2012 |publisher=Montreal Gazette |accessdate=April 5, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===''Maclean's''=== ''[[Maclean's]]'' referred to the four murders as “honouricide”. Writer [[Michael Friscolanti]] sat throughout the three-month trial and wrote a 22-page comprehensive article detailing the girls’ lives and even wrote about how one of the girls’ tombstones has the incorrect birthdate.
“In life, and in death, they had no voice. No one to save them. No one who even cares enough to fix Geeti's headstone. Nearly three years after she was buried, it is still engraved with Sahar's birth-date, not hers."<ref name="macleans1"/>{{Failed verification|date=October 2012}}
==Reaction== The widespread media coverage pressured the Muslim as well as the Afghan community in Canada to come out and speak about the murders.
===Muslims in Canada=== It has also given rise to the debate about the relationship of honour killing and Islam. Islamic organizations based in Canada condemned the murders. The [[Islamic Supreme Council of Canada]], along with other Canadian Muslim organizations, have publicly denounced [[domestic violence]] and [[honour killing]] as un-Islamic.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/story/2011/12/09/toronto-islam-domestic-violence.html|title=Muslim leaders decry domestic violence|publisher=CBC |location=Canada |accessdate=December 10, 2011|date=December 9, 2011}}</ref> Ali Falih Altaie, the family imam, said that the murders were unforgivable, and cautioned against associating honour crimes with Islam, calling the actions incompatible with any religion.<ref name=ctv>{{cite news|title=Shafia deaths unforgivable, says family imam|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120131/shafia-deaths-family-imam-120131/|accessdate=January 31, 2012|newspaper=The Canadian Press via CTV|date=January 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201214018/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120131/shafia-deaths-family-imam-120131/|archivedate=February 1, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/fifth/2011-2012/thehouseofshafia/ |title=The House of Shafia |work=CBC News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212093317/http://www.cbc.ca/fifth/2011-2012/thehouseofshafia/ |archivedate=February 12, 2012 }}</ref>
In 2012 imams from across Canada and the U.S. issued a moral ruling officially condemning honour killings, domestic violence and misogyny as un-Islamic. Thirty-four imams belonging to the Islamic Supreme Council of Canada, including a handful of American members, signed the fatwa in an effort to counter misinterpretations of the Qur'an, they said.
===Afghan Canadians===
The Afghan Embassy in Ottawa in an interview with CTVS News condemned the murders of four members of a Montreal family originally from Afghanistan. The embassy called the deaths of the three teenaged sisters and their father's first wife a heinous crime against humanity. Moreover, they claimed that this kind of crime is not part of Afghan or Islamic culture and is not acceptable in any way.<ref name="Reaction from the Afghan community in Canada">{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120131/hamed-shafia-120131/ |title=Afghan Embassy speaks out against Shafia murders |date=January 31, 2012 |publisher=CTV News |accessdate=April 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304230951/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120131/hamed-shafia-120131 |archivedate=March 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

'''Symbolic Systems''' is an academic program at [[Stanford University]] with an [[interdisciplinarity |interdisciplinary]] concentration on "the science of the mind" including courses in [[computer science]], [[linguistics]], [[philosophy]], and [[psychology]].<ref name=Martinuzzi>{{cite web|last1=Martinuzzi|first1=Bruna|title=Symbolic Systems: The Hot Major Among Highly Successful People|url=https://www.americanexpress.com/us/small-business/openforum/articles/symbolic-systems-the-hot-major-among-highly-successful-people/|website=OPEN Forum|publisher=American Express|accessdate=29 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151129175504/https://www.americanexpress.com/us/small-business/openforum/articles/symbolic-systems-the-hot-major-among-highly-successful-people/|archivedate=2015-11-29|date=September 18, 2013|quote=It's a multidisciplinary major that blends computer science with psychology, linguistics and philosophy |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=Whatis>{{cite web|title=What is Sym Sys?|url=https://symsys.stanford.edu/ssp_description|website=Symbolic Systems Program|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=29 November 2015|quote=majors are required to take courses in the Departments of Computer Science, Linguistics, Philosophy, and Psychology}}</ref> The program is analogous to [[cognitive science]] departments at other schools.
The program offers both bachelor's and master's degrees. The undergraduate major is split into concentrations such as artificial intelligence, human-computer interaction, decision making and rationality, and neuroscience. Student advisors and the student-led Symbolic Systems Society provide support and organize events for the major.<ref name=Society>{{cite web|title=SymSys Society Homepage|url=http://www.symsyssociety.org/|website=Symbolic Systems Society|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref> Each year, the program hosts a "Distinguished Speaker", which in the past have included Daniel Dennett, Steven Pinker, Edward Snowden, and Marvin Minsky.<ref name=Disting>{{cite web|title=Symbolic Systems Distinguished Speaker|url=https://symsys.stanford.edu/viewing/htmldocument/13638|website=Symbolic Systems Program|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
==Notable graduates== *[[Chris Cox (Facebook)|Chris Cox]], Chief Product Officer at Facebook *[[Scott Forstall]] *[[Reid Hoffman]]<ref name=Martinuzzi /> *[[Mike Krieger]]<ref name=Martinuzzi /> *[[Yul Kwon]] *[[Marissa Mayer]]<ref name=Martinuzzi /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://engineering.stanford.edu/press/marissa-mayer-named-ceo-of-yahoo | title=Marissa Mayer named CEO of Yahoo! | publisher=Stanford Engineering | date=16 July 2012 | accessdate=18 August 2014 | author=Dulce, Grace | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819125932/http://engineering.stanford.edu/press/marissa-mayer-named-ceo-of-yahoo | archivedate=19 August 2014 | df= }}</ref> *[[Yuko Munakata]] *[[Srinija Srinivasan]] *[[Tina Chen]] *[[Barney Pell]] *[[Tony Tulathimutte]] *[[Dalton Caldwell]]

{{Infobox person | name = Taddeo Alderotti | image = Florentinus Thaddaeus (Taddeo Alderotti). Line engraving by Wellcome V0005765.jpg | caption = Engraving of Alderotti by Allegrini, 1770 | birth_date = between 1206 and 1215 | birth_place = [[Florence]], [[Italy]] | death_date = 1295 | death_place = [[Bologna]] | occupation = [[Physician]], Professor of Medicine }}
'''Taddeo Alderotti''' ([[Latin]]: '''Thaddaeus Alderottus''', [[French language|French]] : '''Thaddée de Florence'''), born in [[Florence (Italy)|Florence]] between 1206 and 1215, died in 1295, was an Italian doctor and professor of medicine at the [[University of Bologna]], who made important contributions to the renaissance of learned medicine in Europe during the [[High Middle Ages]]. He was among the first to organize a medical lecture at the university.
As an alchemist, he is credited with developing [[fractional distillation]].<ref>{{Cite book|title= Alchemy |last= Holmyard |first= Eric John |year=1990 |publisher= Courier Dover Publications|page= 53|isbn= 0-486-26298-7 }}</ref>
[[Dante]] seems to reference him in the [[Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]] (XII, 82-85), indicating he pursued learning not for spiritual reasons but worldly ambition, contrasting him with [[St. Dominic]].<ref>{{Cite book|title= A History of Medicine Vol. 5 |last= Prioreschi |first= Plinio |year=2003 |publisher= Horatius Press|page= 348|isbn= 1-888456-00-0 }}</ref>
== Life == Taddeo Alderotti was born in [[Florence]], 1210, and received his primary education there.<ref name=Glick>Thomas F. Glick, Steven Livesey, and Faith Wallis, ''Medieval Science, Technology, and Medicine: An Encyclopedia'' (Routledge, 2014)</ref>
In the mid-1260s, Alderotti went to Bologna, a city known for the study and practice of medicine. Through the middle of the fourteenth century, the universities of Bologna, [[University of Montpellier|Montpellier]], and [[University of Paris|Paris]] had a virtual monopoly on medical education in [[Western Europe]].<ref name=jacquart>Danielle Jacquart, "La scolastique médicale," in ''Histoire de la pensée médicale en Occident, vol. 1: Antiquité et Moyen Âge'', edited by Mirko D. Grmek (Seuil, 1995)</ref> As a professor of medicine, Alderotti quickly gained a reputation as an excellent teacher and commanded large crowds of students. His courses relied on the works of [[Hippocrates]], [[Galen]], and [[Avicenna]], which had been given a position of authority since [[Constantine the African]] brought these over from north Africa in the 11th century and translated them.
The students Alderotti taught during his tenure as professor would become some of the best doctors and professors of the next generation. They included, among others, the logician [[Gentile da Cingoli]]; the papal doctor [[Bartolomeo da Varignana]]; [[Dino del Garbo]], commentator of [[Avicenna]]; [[Turisanus]] (Pietro Torregiano de' Torregiani), commentator of Galen; and the anatomist [[Mondino de' Liuzzi]].
A doctor of high repute, Taddeo had a large number of patients, including some far outside Bologna and residing as far away as [[Modena]], [[Ferrara]], [[Rome]], and [[Milan]]. In his old age, he gave up his lectures and he moved his medical practice to Venice.<ref>Plinio Prioreschi, ''Medieval Medicine'' (Horatius Press, 2003)</ref>
Born to a modest Florentine family, Taddeo was by the time of his death in 1295 a rich man. His last will and testament indicates that his medical practice, his lecture, and his investments had paid off handsomely.
== Works == * ''Consilia medicinalia''. Modern edition, Nardi, Turin, 1937. * ''In Claudii Galeni artem parvam commentarii''. Naples, 1522. * ''Expositiones in arduum aphorismorum Hippocratis volumen, in divinum phognosticorum Hippocratis volumen, in praeclarum regiminis acutorum Hippocratis opus, in subtilissimum Joanniti Isagorgarum libellum''. Venice, 1527. *''Sulla conservazione della salute'' or ''Libello per conservare la sanitate''. (''On the preservation of health''.) Latin edition, ''De conservatione sanitatis'', Bologna, 1477; Italian edition, G. Manuzzi and L. Razzolini, eds., Florence, 1863. * ''De virtutibus aquae vitae'' ([[apocryphal]])
==See also== * [[Distillation]] * [[Timeline of chemistry]]

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2011}} [[File:Illustration for 'The Dead' in The Year's at the Spring.jpg|thumb|"Honour has come back, as a king, to earth," illustration by [[Harry Clarke]] in ''The Year's at the Spring'', 1920.]] '''The Dead''' is the name of two poems by [[Rupert Brooke]], parts III and IV of his collection ''[[1914 (poems)|1914]]''. == 1914 == Brooke wrote the five poems that were published in 1914 in the autumn after the outbreak of the [[First World War]] when he enlisted in the [[Royal Naval Division]]. Also in this collection is '[[The Soldier (poem)|The Soldier]]', one of Brooke's most famous poems, though 'The Dead' (IV) was one of his personal favourites. The poems were published in New Numbers before being published in 1914. Brooke published five poems for this collection: I: 'Peace', II: 'Safety', III: 'The Dead', IV: 'The Dead', V: 'The Soldier'. ==III: The Dead== ''Blow out, you bugles, over the rich Dead!''
''There's none of these so lonely and poor of old,''
''But, dying, has made us rarer gifts than gold.''
''These laid the world away; poured out the red''
''Sweet wine of youth; gave up the years to be''
''Of work and joy, and that unhoped serene,''
''That men call age; and those who would have been.''
''Their sons, they gave, their immortality.'' ''Blow, bugles, blow! They brought us, for our dearth.''
''Holiness, lacked so long, and Love, and Pain.''
''Honour has come back, as a king, to earth,''
''And paid his subjects with a royal wage;''
''And Nobleness walks in our ways again;''
''And we have come into our heritage.'' ==IV: The Dead== ''These hearts were woven of human joys and cares,''
''Washed marvellously with sorrow, swift to mirth.''
''The years had given them kindness. Dawn was theirs,''
''And sunset, and the colours of the earth.''
''These had seen movement, and heard music; known''
''Slumber and waking; loved; gone proudly friended;''
''Felt the quick stir of wonder; sat alone;''
''Touched flowers and furs and cheeks. All this is ended.'' ''There are waters blown by changing winds to laughter''
''And lit by the rich skies, all day. And after,''
''Frost, with a gesture, stays the waves that dance''
''And wandering loveliness. He leaves a white''
''Unbroken glory, a gathered radiance,''
''A width, a shining peace, under the night.'' ==Usage== [[File:Blow out your bugles, detail on Memorial Arch (by John M Lyle) at Royal Military College of Canada.JPG|thumb|Inscription on the memorial arch at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]].]] The first three lines of the third poem appear engraved on the [[Memorial arch]] located at the entrance to the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] which commemorated the fallen ex-cadets from World War I onwards. The first eight lines of the third poem appear on [[Royal Naval Division War Memorial]]. ==External links== {{wikisource|The Dead (Brooke)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dead, The}} [[Category:World War I poems]] [[Category:1914 poems]] [[Category:Poems about death]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Redirect|The Egoist|the novel by George Meredith|The Egoist (novel)}} {{Infobox magazine | title = The Egoist | image_file = Egoist1914 72.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = The top half of a yellowed page of a periodical entitled "The Egoist" with "An Individualist Review" as the subtitle and "Formerly the New Freewoman" underneath the subtitle. | image_caption = Masthead from 15 July 1914 issue. | editor = [[Harriet Shaw Weaver]] | editor_title = Editor | previous_editor = [[Dora Marsden]] | staff_writer = | frequency = Monthly
(initially a fortnightly) | circulation = 400 (in 1919) | category = [[Literary magazine]] | company = | publisher = Noah Donnenberg | founded = 1914 | finaldate = 1919 | finalnumber = | country =United Kingdom | based = London | language = English | issn = }} '''''The Egoist''''' (subtitled ''An Individualist Review'') was a London [[literary magazine]] published from 1914 to 1919, during which time it published important early [[modernist]] poetry and fiction. In its manifesto, it claimed to "recognise no taboos,"Caws 340. and published a number of controversial works, such as parts of ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]''.McKenna 100. Today, it is considered "England's most important Modernist periodical."Edwards 144. ==History== ''The Egoist'' was founded by [[Dora Marsden]] as a successor to her feminist magazine ''[[The New Freewoman]]'', but was changed, under the influence of [[Ezra Pound]], into a literary magazine. Pound got his benefactor [[John Quinn (collector)|John Quinn]] to buy him an editorial position in the magazine, and quickly it became a leading publication for [[Imagism|imagist]] poetry.Benstock 364-65. Its group of friends and contributors includes almost every writer of significance of the time, though some, like [[D. H. Lawrence]] (whose "Once" was published in the magazine in 1914), came to denounce it for "editorial sloppiness" and for the philosophical attitudes of its editorial staff.Clarke 148-50. Among the work published in ''The Egoist'' is the work of [[James Joyce]] and [[T. S. Eliot]], as well as letters and criticism.Such as Eliot's response to a charge in the ''[[Times Literary Supplement]]'', see Longenbach 178. Marsden was the editor in the first half of 1914, when it was a fortnightly; for most of its life it was a monthly. Editorship was taken over in July 1914 by [[Harriet Shaw Weaver]].Hughes 31. Assistant editors were [[Richard Aldington]] and Leonard A. Compton-Rickett, with [[H. D.]] When Aldington left in 1917 for the Army, his place was taken by [[T. S. Eliot]],Matherer 49. who was also working on ''Prufrock and other Observations'' at the time (published as a small book by ''The Egoist'').Eliot xiv. When it folded in 1919, there were only 400 subscribers, down from 2,000 in 1911 when it was ''[[The Freewoman]]''.Edwards 145. ==Notable contributions== *[[T. S. Eliot]], "[[Tradition and the Individual Talent]]," vol. 6, nos. 4 & 5 (September & December 1919). *[[James Joyce]], ''[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]'', starting in 1914;Johnson xliii.McKenna 6. three-and-a-half sections of ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'' (1919)McKenna 100. *[[Wyndham Lewis]], ''[[Tarr]]'', April 1916 – November 1917. *[[Charlotte Mew]], "Fête," May 1914Bertram 15. *[[William Carlos Williams]], "The Wanderer" and seven other poems, March 1914; "Transitional" and three other poems, December 1914Williams 477-78. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Works cited== *{{cite book | last = Benstock | first = Shari | authorlink = | title = Women of the Left Bank: Paris, 1900–1940 | publisher = U of Texas P | year = 1987 | isbn = 978-0-292-79040-7}} *{{cite book | last = Bertram | first = Vicki | title = Kicking Daffodils: Twentieth-Century Women Poets | publisher = Edinburgh UP | year = 1997 | page = 15 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4_4RA3Ngk0kC&pg=PA15 | isbn = 978-0-7486-0782-2}} *{{cite book | last = Caws | first = Mary Ann | title = Manifesto: A Century of Isms | publisher = U of Nebraska P | year = 2000 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2xsw-KzaW4sC&pg=PA340 | isbn = 978-0-8032-6407-6}} *{{cite book | last = Clarke | first = Bruce | authorlink = | title = Dora Marsden and Early Modernism: Gender, Individualism, Science | publisher = U of Michigan P | year = 1996 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=07mk2Lx6Y-gC&pg=RA1-PA37 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-472-10646-2}} *Edwards, Paul. "Futurism, Literature and the Market," in {{cite book | last = Marcus | first = Laura | authorlink = |author2=Peter Nicholls | title = The Cambridge history of twentieth-century English literature | publisher = Cambridge UP | year = 2004 | location = | pages = 132–51 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UUInSV7keEUC&pg=PA144 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-521-82077-6}} *Eliot, Valerie. "Introduction," in {{cite book | last = Eliot | first = Thomas Stearns | authorlink = T.S. Eliot |author2=[[Ezra Pound]] | title = The Waste Land: A Facsimile and Transcript of the Original Drafts, Including the Annotations of Ezra Pound | publisher = Houghton Mifflin Harcourt | year = 1974 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iNFu0Im2wPcC&pg=PR12 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-15-694870-8}} *{{cite book | last = Hughes | first = Glenn | authorlink = | title = Imagism & the Imagists: A Study in Modern Poetry | publisher = Biblo & Tannen | year = 1960 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UteQES0-KioC&pg=PA31 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8196-0282-4}} *Johnson, Jeri. "Composition and Publication History," in {{cite book | last = Joyce | first = James | authorlink = James Joyce |author2=Jeri Johnson | title = A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man | publisher = Oxford UP | year = 2000 | location = Oxford | pages = xl–xliii | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RbGAVT0JF_kC&pg=PR42 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-19-283998-5}} *Longenbach, James. "'Mature Poets Steal': Eliot's Allusive Practice," in {{cite book | last = Moody | first = Anthony David | authorlink = | title = The Cambridge Companion to T.S. Eliot | publisher = Cambridge UP | year = 1994 | location = Cambridge | pages = 176–88 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2yIc1jYM5o4C&pg=PA178 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-521-42127-0}} *Matherer, Timothy. "T.S. Eliot's Critical Program," in {{cite book | last = Moody | first = Anthony David | authorlink = | title = The Cambridge Companion to T.S. Eliot | publisher = Cambridge UP | year = 1994 | location = Cambridge | pages = 48–76 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2yIc1jYM5o4C&pg=PA49 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-521-42127-0}} *{{cite book | last = McKenna | first = Bernard | authorlink = | title = James Joyce's Ulysses: a reference guide | publisher = Greenwood | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4spIp7sUtSoC | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-313-31625-8}} *{{cite book | last = Symons | first = Julian | authorlink = Julian Symons | title = Makers of the New: The Revolution in Literature, 1912–1939 | publisher = Andre Deutsch | year = 1987 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-233-98007-5}} *{{cite book | last = Williams | first = William Carlos | authorlink = Andrew Carlos Williams |author2=A. Walton Litz |author3=Christopher John MacGowan | title = The Collected Poems of William Carlos Williams | publisher = New Directions | year = 1986 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Ka59wYp-gVwC&pg=PA477 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8112-0999-1}} ==External links== * [http://dl.lib.brown.edu/mjp/render.php?view=mjp_object&id=EgoistCollection ''The Egoist''] at the [[Modernist Journals Project]]: cover-to-cover, searchable digital edition of all 6 volumes (comprising 74 issues) from No 1.1 (1 January 1914) to No. 6.5 (December 1919). PDFs of these issues may be downloaded for free from the MJP website. * [http://www.nonserviam.com/egoistarchive/marsden/TheEgoist/index.html Articles online], from ''The Egoist'' Archive at nonserviam.com *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100707112908/http://modernism.research.yale.edu/wiki/index.php/The_Egoist Account of ''The Egoist''], at Modernism Lab Essays, a [[Yale University]] website {{DEFAULTSORT:Egoist}} [[Category:1914 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1919 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British monthly magazines]] [[Category:Defunct British literary magazines]] [[Category:Egoism]] [[Category:Fortnightly magazines]] [[Category:London magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1914]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1919]] [[Category:T. {{Redirect|Cercaria|text=Cercaria is also a synonym for ''[[Euglena]]''.}}
[[File:TrematodesFig8 EncBrit1911.png|thumb|Life-history stages of the trematode flatworm ''Fasciola hepatica'' from 1911 ''Encyclopædia Britannica'']] [[Trematodes]] are any parasitic [[flatworm]] of the class ''Trematoda'', especially a parasitic fluke. While consisting of two suckers, one being [[ventral]] and one being oral. They have a [[Tegument (helminth)|tegument]] covering which helps them with absorption and protection from the environment.
The life cycle of a typical trematode begins when the egg is immersed in water or from the adult worms in the definitive host. Some trematode eggs hatch in water, others are eaten by the first intermediate host and hatch within that host, so there are many different routes that a trematode could take to infect a host. Following this, the miracidium, which is free-swimming ciliated larva that a parasite moves from the egg to host stage, hatches which then also goes to find the mollusc host as the first intermediate host. This is where either a rediae or sporocyst will form depending on the host and if there is competition between the two. This eventually forms into a motile cercariae. The cercariae then either infects vertebrates through the skin of a host or is ingested and aims to locate the second intermediate host. When in the vertebrate host, the cercariae can then form into an adult, metacercariae or mesocercariae, depending on the life cycle, or is rejected through feces or urine. Then the metacercariae and second intermediate host has to be ingested by the definitive host for the life cycle to be completed.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1471-4922(02)02262-6 |pmid=11998706 |title=Trematode life cycles: Short is sweet? |journal=Trends in Parasitology |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=176–83 |year=2002 |last1=Poulin |first1=Robert |last2=Cribb |first2=Thomas H }}</ref>
==Typical life cycle stages== [[File:Parasite140042-fig2 Clinostomum phalacrocoracis metacercariae in fish.tif|thumb|[[Metacercaria]]e of ''[[Clinostomum phalacrocoracis]]'' in fish<ref name="CaffaraDavidovich2014">{{cite journal |doi=10.1051/parasite/2014034 |pmid=24986336 |pmc=4078730 |title=Redescription of ''Clinostomum phalacrocoracis'' metacercariae (Digenea: Clinostomidae) in cichlids from Lake Kinneret, Israel |journal=Parasite |volume=21 |pages=32 |year=2014 |last1=Caffara |first1=Monica |last2=Davidovich |first2=Nadav |last3=Falk |first3=Rama |last4=Smirnov |first4=Margarita |last5=Ofek |first5=Tamir |last6=Cummings |first6=David |last7=Gustinelli |first7=Andrea |last8=Fioravanti |first8=Maria L }}</ref>]]
[[File:Haeckel Platodes Bucephalus.png|thumb|Bucephalid cercaria larva from [[Ernst Haeckel]]'s ''[[Kunstformen der Natur]]'' (1904): The tail's [[Furcula (springtail)|furca]]e give the impression of horns, hence the genus name ''[[Bucephalus (trematode)|Bucephalus]]'' meaning "ox head".]]
While the details vary with each [[species]], the general life cycle stages are: ===Egg=== Found in either feces, sputum or in the urine. Depending on the species it will either be unembryonated (immature) or embryonated (ready to hatch), while all are operculated besides schistosomes. Some eggs are eaten by the host (snail) or hatch in the environment first when coming into contact with water.
===Miracidium (plural miracidia)=== These hatch from the eggs and switches to locate the host. They do not have a mouth therefore cannot eat and need to find the host quickly in order to survive because they have a limited amount of energy, which will then develop into the mother sporocyst. Its main function is to infect the first intermediate host, which can differ for different trematodes.<ref>Galaktionov, K. V., & Dobrovolʹskiĭ, A. A. (2003). The biology and evolution of trematodes: An essay on the biology, morphology, life cycles, transmission, and evolution of digenetic trematodes. Dordrecht: Kluwer Academic.{{pn|date=May 2018}}</ref>
===Sporocyst=== Elongated sac that produces either more sporocyst or rediae. This is where larva can be to develop.<ref>Fried, Bernard, and Thaddeus K. Graczyk. Echinostomes as Experimental Models for Biological Research. Springer, 2011.{{pn|date=May 2018}}</ref> *''Mother Sporocyst'': They have loose plates (cilia) and migrate to gonas. *''Daughter Sporocyst'': They are an asexual production of cercariae, they absorb nutrients while having no mouth.
===Redia (plural rediae)=== After the sporocyst form the larva, the first development from it forms the redia. <ref>Fried, Bernard, and Thaddeus K. Graczyk. Echinostomes as Experimental Models for Biological Research. Springer, 2011.{{pn|date=May 2018}}</ref> They have a mouth which allows them to have an advantage to their competitors because they can just consume them. Will either produce more rediae or start to form cercariae. The amount of rediae or daughter sporocyst varies a lot in the representatives of different deign taxa. <ref>Galaktionov, K. V., & Dobrovolʹskiĭ, A. A. (2003). The biology and evolution of trematodes: An essay on the biology, morphology, life cycles, transmission, and evolution of digenetic trematodes. Dordrecht: Kluwer Academic.{{pn|date=May 2018}}</ref>
====Parasite Competition in Snail Hosts==== Co-infections of different parasite species within the same post could occur and cause a competition between the rediae and sporocysts. Not all trematode species have a rediae stage, some may just have a sporocyst stage depending on the life cycle. The rediae are dominant to sporocyst because they have a "mouth" and are able to either eat their competitors' food or their competitor.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
===Cercaria (plural cercariae)=== The larval form of the parasite, it develops within the germinal cells of the sporocyst or redia.<ref name="glossary">{{cite web|url=http://cal.vet.upenn.edu/projects/parasit06/website/glossary.htm|title=Glossary|work=VPTH 603 Veterinary Parasitology|publisher=University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine}}</ref> A cercaria has a tapering head with large penetration glands.<ref name=schistosoma/> It may or may not have a long swimming "tail", depending on the species.<ref name=glossary/> The motile cercaria finds and settles in a host where it will become either an adult, or a mesocercaria, or a metacercaria, according to species.
*Mesocercaria: They are involved in an encysted stage either on vegetation or in a host tissue on the second intermediate host. They have a hard shell and are also involved in the trophic transmission. This is where the parasite is able to infect the definitive host because it consumes the second intermediate host that has metacercariae on/in it.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
*Metacercaria: A cercaria [[cyst|encysted]] and resting.They are only involved when there are 3 intermediate host life cycles.
''Cercaria'' is also used as a genus of trematodes, when adult forms are not known.<ref>[http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=728666 ''Cercaria''] at WoRMS</ref> The usage dates back to Müller, in 1773.<ref>Vermium terrestrium et fluviatilium seu animalium infusoriorum, helminthicorum et testaceorum, non marinorum, succincta historia. OF Müller, 1773</ref>
===Adult=== The fully developed mature stage, it is capable of sexual reproduction.
==Deviations from the typical life cycle== Not all trematodes follow the typical sequence of eggs, miracidia, sporocysts, rediae, cercariae, and adults. In some species, the redial stage is omitted, and sporocysts produce cercariae. In some species, the cercaria develops into an adult within the same host.
Many digenean trematodes require two hosts, one (typically a snail) where asexual reproduction occurs in sporocysts, the other a vertebrate (typically a fish) where the adult form engages in sexual reproduction to produce eggs. In some species (for example ''[[Ribeiroia]]'') the cercaria [[encyst]]s, and waits until the host is eaten by a third host, in whose gut it emerges and develops into an adult.
Most trematodes are [[hermaphroditic]], but members of the family [[Schistosomatidae]] are [[dioecious]]. Males are shorter and stouter than the females.<ref name=schistosoma>{{cite web|title=Schistosoma|url=http://parasite.org.au/para-site/text/schistosoma-text.html|publisher=Australian Society for Parasitology|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
==Representations of life cycles of several different trematode species== [[File:Trematode lifecycle stages.png|thumb|400px|center|Life cycle stages of a digenean human parasite, ''[[Schistosoma japonicum]]'']] [[File:Bucephaluslifecycle.jpg|thumb|400px|center|Life cycle stages of a digenean fish parasite, ''[[Bucephalus polymorphus]]'']] [[File:Cercarial_LifeCycle.png|thumb|400px|center|Life cycle stages of trematode species that cause "[[swimmer's itch]]"]]

{{Unreferenced|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Yi Ui-Bang
이의방 | office = [[Military Leader of Goryeo]] | term_start = ? | term_end = 1174 | predecessor = Position established | successor = [[Jeong Jung-bu]] | birth_date = 1121 | death_date = 1174 | spouse = unknown spouse | children = unknown daughter | monarch = [[Uijong of Goryeo|King Uijong]]
[[Myeongjong of Goryeo]] }} {{Korean name|[[Lee (Korean name)|Yi]]}} {{Infobox Korean name | hangul = {{linktext|이|의|방|}} | hanja = {{linktext|李|義|方|}} |rr=I Ui-bang |mr=Yi Ŭibang }} '''Yi Ui-bang''' ({{lang|ko|이의방}}, 1121 - December 1174) was a military ruler of [[Korea]] during the [[Goryeo]] period. == Life == ===Background=== Yi originated from the Jeonju Yi clan (전주이씨; 全州李氏). He subsequently joined the military and rose in ranks, becoming a minister in the scholar dominated government. ===Rebellion=== In August 1170 ([[Uijong of Goryeo|Uijong]] 24th year), he joined the Goryeo warrior rebellion, which occurred in defiance against the typically scholar/minister ruled Korea. Primary leaders of this rebellion was [[Jeong Jung-bu]] and [[Yi Go]] who found that warrior-class treatment was truly unfair and planned a coup e tat to establish a warrior government. The [[King of Goryeo]], [[Uijong of Goryeo|Uijong]] was soon disposed and the new warrior-class ministers set up a puppet king [[Myeongjong of Goryeo|Myeongjong]]. Yi was named as one of the key figures in the new regime with the title of High Merit Minister (壁上功臣) and given special privileges along with the other ministers. When Yi Go tried to plot a coup and get hold of a dictatorship in 1171, Yi, under the orders of Chung Jung-bu purged and murdered Yi Go. ===Governance=== With Jeong, Yi increased the size and power of the military and attracted military-class administrators to the regime and appointed these men to national offices which were previously reserved for scholar-class ministers. In 1173, when a scholar-class minister Kim Bo-dang (김보당 金甫當) attempted to restore disposed king Uijong to the throne, Yi decisively slew the former king, preventing any further restoration attempts. With this merit, he was further promoted to Commander of Land Troops. During his co-governance with Jeong, Yi also faced a series of Buddhist Monk uprisings from different shrines around the nation. As Goryeo was officially a Buddhist nation since [[Taejo of Goryeo|Wangkon]]'s unification of Korea, the Buddhists had great influence upon the government and most Goryeo kings appointed official Buddhist Great Monk advisors to assist in national administration. Due to the increasing Buddhist uprisings, Yi himself commanded his forces to put down these rebellions and raid Buddhist shrines. With his powerful forces, he swept the nation and raided and pillaged these shrines. At this time, [[Jo Wi-chong]] (조위총, 趙位寵), a general of the North-Western border attempted to start a rebellion. Yi responded by murdering favorers of this rebellion such as [[Yun In-mi]] (윤인미, 尹仁美), who was of [[Pyongyang|Seogyung]] birth. Due to this action, Yi lost support and favors from the people, and when he attempted to put down this rebellion, he failed. ===Downfall and death=== Yi, attempting to put down Jeong and gain more power, tried to appoint his daughter as Royal [[Prince consort]], an action which did not fulfill objective but instead further endangered Yi's political situation. Due to this action, the 2nd Jo Invasion force, led by Jeong Jung-bu's son Jeong Gyun subsequently murdered Yi Ui-Bang and his supporters and removed his daughter from the royal family. However, soon enough, Jeong Jung-bu was also murdered and the young and righteous dictator [[Gyeong Dae-seung]] took power. ==Legacy== General Yi Ui-bang's main legacy remains in the balance that was achieved through the purging of scholars during his co-governance with Jeong. Before the arrival of Yi, the scholar class had more influence in the government to the extent that the warrior-class was greatly mistreated. With the changing of kings and shifting of power from scholar-class to warrior-class, Goryeo faced a new era. A final and very important legacy is his connection with the founder of the [[Joseon Dynasty]], [[Yi Songgye]]. Yi Ui-Bang's younger brother Yi In was a 6th generation ancestor of Yi Songgye, thus connecting Yi Ui-Bang and Yi Songgye together. ==References== *http://mtcha.com.ne.kr/koreaman/goryo/man93-iyibang.htm : 차석찬의 역사창고 *http://enc.daum.net/dic100/viewContents.do?&m=all&articleID=b18a0210a *http://www.encyber.com/biodic/contents_n.php?cd=1602&p=4&masterno=127558&haksupno=1742 *http://kr.dic.yahoo.com/search/enc/result.html?pk=17174900 ==See also== *[[History of Korea]] *[[List of Korea-related topics]] *[[List of Goryeo people]] {{start box}} {{succession box|years=?–1174|title=[[Military Leader of Goryeo]]|before=–|after=[[Jeong Jung-bu]]}} {{end box}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yi, Ui-bang}} [[Category:Goryeo people]] [[Category:Korean generals]] [[Category:1174 deaths]] [[Category:1121 births]] [[Category:Regents of Korea]] [[Category:Murder victims]] [[Category:People from Jeonju]] [[Category:Leaders who took power by coup]] [[Category:Leaders ousted by a coup]] [[Category:House of Yi|Ui-bang]] [[Category:Yi clan of Jeonju]]
